works.notes: 3Unit's "SOS" was confirmed to be written about climate change in personal correspondence with the songwriters. The title of the song, which represents a pattern that is easy to send in Morse Code and was often used as an emergency message on ships, is an allusion to the planet in a state of emergency. The song only has a chorus: "Save our souls / they'll be lost forever / Trees of green / they'll be gone forever." Lyrics verified in personal correspondence.

works.work_title: Spitting Off the Edge of the World feat. Perfume Genius
works.notes: The Yeah Yeah Yeahs' song "Spitting Off the Edge of the World" featuring Perfume Genius is included in the database for multiple implicit references to climate change in the lyrics, album art, and music video, as well as confirmation directly from songwriter Karen O. that the song was inspired by the climate crisis. Karen O. is quoted in multiple media outlets, including Rolling Stone and Paste, tying the inspiration for the song to the ongoing climate crisis: "We’re all experiencing this climate crisis through a system which is broken and not really addressing it... I see the younger generations staring down the threat, and they’re standing on the edge of a precipice, confronting what’s coming with anger and defiance" (Rolling Stone, Paste). The album cover depicts a woman holding a purse flying through the air upside down, and flames and smoke can be seen on the lower edge of the image, possibly referencing forest fires. The song lyrics offer the listener a foreboding reflection on facing a crisis, with a specific reference to the sun: "We're spitting off the edge of the world (out in the night) / Never had no chance (nowhere to hide) / Spitting off the edge of the world (out comes the sun) / Never had no chance (nowhere to run)" (Genius Lyrics). In the song's music video, Karen O. can be seen standing on top of an enormous gas-guzzling limousine decorated with spikes as if for battle with featured artist Perfume Genius in the driver's seat (YouTube).

works.notes: "Landing Gear" by Ani Difranco, a reflection on parenthood and taking care of the earth, is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. In the first verse, DiFranco uses the image of a polar bear stranded in the ocean to describe her own exhaustion, which clearly indicates ice melt due to global warming: "Cuz i am as exhausted / As a drowning polar bear / Swimming around looking for a ride" (Genius Lyrics). It is well established that reductions in sea ice caused by climate change are affecting polar bear populations (Global Change Biology). To further connect the song to global warming, DiFranco also sings "And it's so god-awful hot outside" as the next lyric (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Bad Religion's "Changing Tide" is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. The song describes a person going through the motions of an ordinary life and waiting for an opportunity, suddenly confronted with changing circumstances: "Every day's the same routine / Of endless chores and boring details / And you know you're waiting for the perfect / Condition for your ship to set sail / But of course the climate's always changing / Clinging to the past has got you straining / Comes the recognition now / You're on a mission that is born to fail / (Leave it!) / Brothers, say goodbye / Sisters, don't you cry / All, embrace the times / Wade into the changing tide" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Here, climate change is directly referenced as an example of changing circumstances. "Changing tide," a second reference to the natural world, is also used in the comparison, which may refer to sea level rise, but that is not confirmed.

works.notes: Damian Marley's "Time Travel" is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming within a dark and detailed set of worries about what the future holds for the next generation. The first chorus, following an opening verse filled with references to crime, inequality, and advances in technology, reflects on the future world that Marley and his son will inhabit: "What will the future bring for me? / Cause global warming feels so cold / What will the future bring? What will the future bring? / What will the future bring for me / If my little son is seven years old / What will the future bring for him? What will the future bring?" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Don Henley's "Praying For Rain" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change, as well as confirmation in interviews that the song is about climate change. The song is written from the perspective of a farmer struggling with long-term changes in weather patterns, specifically droughts and heat. Lyric snippets: "Something's different, something's changed / And I don't know why / Even the old folks can't recall / When it's ever been this hot and dry / Dust devils whirlin' on the first day of July / It's a hundred degrees at 10:00 AM / Not a cloud up in the sky / We hardly had a winter / Had about a week of spring / Crops are burned-up in the fields / There's a blanket of dust on everything" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Henley confirmed in a 2015 interview with USA Today that the song is about climate change (USA Today).

works.notes: A live performance of Fatboy Slim's song "Right Here, Right Now" is included in the database for using a sample of Greta Thunberg's 2019 speech urging the United Nations to take action on climate change. The live version includes a portion of the speech: "...and yet, I'm one of the lucky ones. People are suffering. People are dying. Entire ecosystems are collapsing. We are in the beginning of a mass extinction, and all you can talk about is money and fairy tales... You are failing us. But the young people are starting to understand your betrayal. The eyes of all future generations are upon you... We will not let you get away with this. Right here, right now is where we draw the line. The world is waking up. And change is coming..." (YouTube, NPR). A looped sample of Greta saying "Right Here, Right Now" is substituted for the original sample of the same words.

works.notes: "Veruca's Nutcracker Sweet," a song from the original London production of the musical "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. The song, which is performed during a scene in which trained squirrels judge the spoiled brat Veruca Salt to be a "bad nut" and throw her down a garbage chute while her rich father looks on in horror, includes a line about her lack of concern for the environment: "To the furnace we bequeath her / See the squirrels as they are swarming / Thought recycling was beneath her / She’s the cause of global warming" (Genius Lyrics). This unmistakable reference may be a comment on class and wastefulness, or even an indictment of the world's wealthiest people for contributing the most to climate change, but this interpretation is unconfirmed.

works.notes: "VISION" by Dreamcatcher is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change in the context of the narrative arc of their "Apocalypse" album trilogy. The group has also explicitly discussed in interviews how "VISION" and the mini-album it appears on, "Apocalypse: Follow Us," tell a story about resisting climate change. In a 2022 interview with Bandwagon, band leader JiU explained that "In this mini-album, we talk about heading towards the same direction as one to ﬁght against climate change. We want to show that we can achieve anything if we put our hearts and minds into it!" (bandwagon.asia). In the lyrics for "VISION," the group sings about banding together as soldiers fighting a battle in the setting of a broken world specifically affected by droughts: "In this place drier than the desert / This unquenchable thirst / Above the cracks of Earth / Raise your flag and stand your ground / I can't take it, I can't hide any longer / Forward march" (Genius lyrics English translation). In the music video, the members of Dreamcatcher dance in military uniforms in front of a post-apocalyptic urban background, furthering the war imagery motif (YouTube).

works.notes: "Shut It Down" is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. The song is a call to action to "shut the whole system down" and "Start again and build it for eternity," implying in a broad sense that systems humans have built are unsustainable. The explicit reference occurs at the end of the first verse: "(Have to shut the whole system down) / All around the planet / There's a blindness that just can't see / (Have to shut the whole system down) / They're all wearing climate change / As cool as they can be" (Genius Lyrics, audio tracks).

works.notes: "World On Fire" by Dolly Parton is included in the database for a very strong implicit reference to climate change, despite the singer's choice not to explicitly mention the issue in the song's lyrics or in interviews about the song. The song directly takes aim at politicians and political division as a theme: "Don't get me started on politics / Now how are we to live in a world like this? / Greedy politicians, present and past / They wouldn't know the truth if it bit 'em in the ass" (Genius Lyrics). In interviews about the song, this is the theme that she generally chooses to discuss, as she did in an interview with TODAY's Jacob Soboroff that aired May 15 (today.com). Parton's career-long tendency not to align herself too strongly one way or the other on political issues, including the climate, is discussed in depth in climate news website Grist's analysis of the song, which does not draw a conclusion about whether or not the song was intended to be about climate change (Grist). However, despite this (likely intentional) ambiguity, the song contains multiple lyrics that are very hard to imagine outside of the context of a warming world in 2023 following several consecutive years of record-breaking wildfire disasters and decades of climate denial by US politicians: "Liar, liar, the world's on fire / What you gonna do when it all burns down? / Fire, fire, burnin' higher / Still got time to turn it all around" (Genius Lyrics). The idea that there is "still time to turn it all around," in particular, calls to mind the time-sensitive task of lowering greenhouse gas emissions to prevent the worst possible impacts of climate change. Lying politicians (climate deniers), a world on fire (a warming world, or literally, a world full of climate-change accelerated wildfires), a call to action ("turn it all around"), imagery of protesting ("Janie got a sign to carry in the fight / Marchin' in the streets with sticks and stones), and album art featuring Parton sitting on a globe going up in flames, together form one of the most powerful implicit references to the climate crisis in the entire database. Parton may have intentionally created this message for those who choose to see it, but even if she did not, this song offers the public an obvious and compelling choice for a potential climate anthem.

works.notes: "The Sea is Rising" by Bliss n Eso is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The chorus mentions both ice melting and sea level rise in the same line: "And all I know is the sun is shining / Yet we fight all through the night / While the 'bergs are melting (Yeah) and the sea is rising / I don't know, so I ask 'em why" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). The remaining lyrics cover a wide variety of topics but frequently focus on war and other conflicts are distracting people from the environment: "I don't want them to look back when the future was written / And know we killed ourselves / With nuclear fission and stupid decisions / Shit, I'd rather an asteroid due for collision / Then know the planet got fucked by the human condition" (Genius lyrics, audio track).

works.notes:
"Good Soldier" by Flobots is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming and discussion of its anthropogenic nature. During the first verse, rapper Jonny 5 says "What's bald in the morning, but in the evening has white hairs?
What's the cause of Global Warming, and could it be these things right here?" (Genius Lyrics). These lyrics appear to form two rhetorical questions emphasizing the human causes of climate change. An unverified annotation on Genius Lyrics suggests that the first question is a reference to the Riddle of the Sphinx from the Greek tragedy "Oedipus Rex," to which the answer is "humans," also answering the second question about the cause of global warming (Genius Lyrics, Wikipedia).

works.work_title: Global Warming Christmas (There Is No Snow In Kalamazoo)
works.notes: "Global Warming Christmas (There Is No Snow In Kalamazoo)" is a Christmas single recorded by country musician Sherwin Linton. The song appears to lament the effects of global warming on Santa Claus' appearance and North Pole operations, and it contains numerous expressions of skepticism about the role of regulations in combating global warming. It also notably references the 2006 climate change documentary An Inconvenient Truth. Lyric snippet: "A letter addressed to Santa Claus / Said he just might be part of the cause / The EPA won't let him be / They're crackin' down at his factory / It's time he thinks about goin' green / Or the government will intervene / Seems makin' all those toys each year / Is having an effect on the atmosphere / Having an effect on the atmosphere / There is no snow in Kalamazoo / It's melting at the North Pole too / Blame it on the CO2 / Cause there is no snow in Kalamazoo / Son Dasher and Dancer and all the rest / Will have to take an emissions test / They better pass without a Poot / They'll be grounded if they pollute / They'll be grounded if they pollute / Now Santa's talkin' retirement / With all this stress on the environment / but how can he tell little Tommy and Ruth / About an inconvenient truth / About an inconvenient truth" (discogs).

works.notes: JID's "LeTrow" is included in the database for explicit references to climate change via an extended sample of actor and climate activist Leonardo DiCaprio's 2014 speech at the United Nations Climate Summit in New York City. JID and guest 6LACK perform verses about their early careers and Georgia roots that are interspersed with segments of the DiCaprio speech, including this excerpt: "Every week, we’re seeing new and undeniable events, evidence that accelerated climate change is here now. Droughts are intensifying, our oceans are acidifying, with methane plumes rising up from beneath the ocean floor. We are seeing extreme weather events, and the West Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheets melting at unprecedented rates, decades ahead of scientific projections" (Genius Lyrics). The EP on which this song appears is named simply "DiCaprio," and an image of DiCaprio's face appears on the album art.

works.notes: "Global Warming" is the final track on Melissa Schiller's debut full-length album, "Misunderstandings." The song was written by Nicholas Taniguchi and performed as a duet between Nicholas and Melissa. The song uses an extended set of references to global warming and other environmental issues (like the hole in the ozone layer) to discuss love. The song mentions melting glaciers, the effect of melting sea ice on polar bears, carbon emissions, global warming, and rising sea levels. Lyric snippet: "you melt the polar-knitted ice caps from off of my head / and now I’m drenched to the bone / your lips are global warming / and I’m a glacier melting / as I stand here to the north of you / you’ve got the scientists stumped / there’s not much that can be done / so I’ll wait for the day when all this is through / I saw a polar bear without a patch of ice / to call his own thanks to you / you’ve got me dizzy, spinning circles / falling down inside my room from the CO2" (bandcamp).

works.notes: Kyoto Now! is included in the database for a reference to the Kyoto Protocol, an international framework for limiting greenhouse gas emissions from industrialized countries in order to prevent further climate change. The United States did not ratify the Kyoto Protocol. The song's lyrics criticize inaction on climate change: "Don't allow / This mythologic, hopeful monster to exact its price / Kyoto now / We can't do nothing and think someone else will make it right / You might not think it matters now / But what if you are wrong? / You might not think there's any wisdom / In a fucked up punk rock song / But the way it is cannot persist for long / A brutal sun is rising on a sick horizon" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: Scorpions' "Humanity" is included in the database for a lyrical reference to sea level rise, climate imagery in the music video, and support of environmental activist group Greenpeace's Amazon rainforest campaign during the Humanity World Tour 2007. The song's bridge warns of several disasters, including sea-level rise, and blames humans for it: "Run and hide there's fire in the sky / Stay inside / The water's gonna rise and pull you under / In your eyes I'm staring at the end of time / Nothing can change us / No one can save us from ourselves" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). This lyric snippet alone does not conclusively tie the song to climate change, knowing that the album is about a futurist war that occurs when humans lose control of artificial intelligence  (Wikipedia). However, the "Humanity' music video begins with an image earth in space behind the band, and throughout the video, short video clips of various scenes play, including parched desert earth and an animation of the earth engulfed in flames (YouTube). Furthermore, Scorpions supported the climate activist group Greenpeace during the 2007 tour to support the album, at one point hanging a Greenpeace poster on stage reading "Stop Deforestation, No Amazon, No Future" in Portugese (media.greenpeace.org).

works.notes: "Calentamiento Global" by Solo Borges is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming in the title and a direct implication of humanity as the cause of climate change. According to the band's entry on Encyclopaedia Metallum and the single listed in the band's Spotify catalog, the song was released in 2019 and then included as part of the 2021 album "Mundo Viral". Lyrics snippet: "Tendran que apagar el fuego / El fuego que prendimos / Sin darnos cuenta matamos / La tierra esta Calentandose / Tenemos que dejar de quemar" (musixmatch). Rough English translation: "We will have to put out the fire / The fire that we light / We kill without realizing it / The world is heating up / We have to stop burning" (Google Translate).

works.notes: Thom Yorke's "And It Rained All Night" is included in the database based on lyrical references to urban flooding and other context tying the song to climate change, including the songwriter's involvement in climate activism and the album art's relationship to climate change. The lyrics depict an imminent flood disaster: "And it rained all night and washed the filth away / Down New York air conditioned drains / Oh the click click clack of the heavy black trains / A million engines in neutral / Oh the tick tock tick of the ticking time bomb / Fifty feet of concrete underground / One little leak becomes a lake" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Thom Yorke is a known environmental activist, taking action with groups including 350.org and Friends of the Earth, organizing environmentally conscious concert tours, and appearing at climate-change focused events (Wikipedia). In a 2006 interview with The Chicago Tribune, Yorke described a connection between the album's artwork (a depiction of King Canute attempting to hold back a flood engulfing London) and the writing of environmentalist Jonathan Porritt comparing King Canute's failure to the United Kingdom's response to climate change (Chicago Tribune).

works.notes: "Dead Polar Bears (Stop Global Warming!)" by Matt Farley, released under the artist name "The Strange Man Who Sings About Dead Animals," is included in the database for referencing the effects of melting polar ice from global warming on the survival of polar bears. Lyrics snippet: "I feel so very sad for all the dead polar bears / We've got to stop making the earth so hot so they can continue to be alive" (YouTube audio). The long term survival of polar bears is threatened by melting polar ice that they use as habitat, and this is caused by climate change (Global Change Biology).

works.notes: "We're Not Alone" by Nas is included in the database for a specific reference to global warming. The song also contains pro-environment themes, alongside discussion of racial oppression and economic inequalities. The specific global warming reference occurs in a verse about the oppression of black people in America, highlighting this as an additional hardship black people must now face: "My pimp strut was invented when they whipped us / Now we diddy bop just to show you that our strength's up / Just when n****s 'bout to see they cut / Global warming about to burn us up" (Genius Lyrics). Additional lyrics conveying environmental themes, including specific mention of the weather changing over time, are sung by Mykel in the intro: "Where there's life there is water / We depend on Mama Nature / There's a message for tomorrow / Everything connects to you / Some say soon it will be over / You can see it in the weather / Out of tune with Mama Nature / What you do comes back to you" (Genius Lyrics).

works.work_title: WHAT THE HELL ARE WE DYING FOR?
works.notes: "WHAT THE HELL ARE WE DYING FOR?" by Shawn Mendes is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to smoke from the 2023 Canadian wildfires, which formed in conditions exacerbated by climate change (Wikipedia). Furthermore, the song's album art consists entirely of the New York City skyline barely visible through orange smoke from the same wildfires, making the connection extremely clear. The lyrics make multiple references to air quality, including the phrase "smoke in the air" and the use of hyperbole in the phrase "the city's burning down," reflecting on just how dystopian the orange sky looks: "Smoke in the air, the city's burnin' down / I wanna speak, but I don't make a sound / Locked in my mind, you're all I think about (Mm) / I wanna save us, but I don't know how" (Genius lyrics). In the second verse, Mendes refers to the news (which was full of information about the wildfires at that time) and choking, which both again connect to the air quality emergency: "I see it in the news, I see it in your eyes, oh / I try to let you go, then I choke, I change my mind / (Change my mind, ooh) / Let's face thе truth, I'm terrified (Ooh, ooh)" (Genius lyrics). The lyrics reflect multiple narratives at once, including one about a relationship in parallel with the air quality theme, and Mendes confirmed in an interview that the environment (but not climate change specifically) was one inspiration for the song: "I was upstate New York and just on the back end of feeling a lot of things about relationships, about my career, about the environment. I was in the studio and this moment of just deep frustration came over me and I finally started to feel this inspiration come" (Billboard). However, the unmistakable connection to the climate change-exacerbated Canadian wildfires through the lyrics and the album art qualify the song for inclusion in the database even without explicit confirmation from the artist that the song is specifically about climate change.

works.notes: Bob Seger's "It's Your World" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change within a general environmental call to action. Seger specifically refers to ocean acidification and its effect on coral reefs (a result of carbon emissions accumulating in the atmosphere) and melting arctic and tundra ice in the opening verse: "Let's talk about acid in the ocean / Let's look at all the dying coral reefs / Let's talk about shorter growing seasons / Let's talk about what we're gonna eat / Say a prayer for the victims of extinction / Say another for the redwood trees / Say another for arctic and the tundra / Let's talk about who we're tryin' to please" (Genius Lyrics, audio track, NASA).
works.media_link_title: NASA - Ocean Acidification

works.notes: Bob Seger's "The Fireman's Talkin'" is included for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The chorus of the song warns of a large change on the horizon, and the verses very specifically indicate that it is climate change by referencing ice melt, sea level rise, and (with the context of the song title) forest fires: "The fireman's talkin' like heroes do / You best start listenin' when he gets to you / The ice is meltin', the seas are high / The smoke keeps risin' and there's no more time / You know you're out of time / There's no more hidin' the truth away / A change is comin', it's on the way / It won't be sudden, it might take years / It might take decades but it will get here / You know it will get here / You know it will get here" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

Testament's "Greenhouse Effect" is included in the database for an explicit reference to the Greenhouse Effect, a main driver of climate change, in the song title. Additionally, the lyrics reference environmental destruction including wildfires in South America and misleading coverage in the media. Lyric snippets: "Fools the ones who stray, the rain forest burns away / Know what to believe, this is the air we breathe / So the world we know is dying slow in South America / Flames are burning down, all the trees to the ground / Time is running low, we can't stay no more / Wealth these people see, fight for eternity / Lies they televise paid by the government / There on! It lingers on / And they don't even care if they... / Seal the planet's fate / Crimes they perpetrate / Wasting precious land / It's time to take a stand" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Venusian I," named for a spaceship carrying humans away from earth to avoid environmental catastrophe, is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. Following the arc of the concept album's story, the song opens with lines describing the environmental destruction on earth driving humans to escape: "Forest desertified / Ocean wave amplify / Constant tornado sky / Black water, no supply / Otherworld, surrogate / Interstellar our escape" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). These lyrics specifically describe both deforestation (a cause of climate change) and increases in storm surge (a result of climate change), as well as frequent storm conditions and water access issues.

works.notes: Brad Paisley's "Gone Green" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song ties together electric vehicles (a low carbon technology), solar energy (a renewable, low carbon energy source), and the need to move past fossil fuels (the source of carbon emissions and thus climate change) through the experiences of individuals living in rural America. The song leans into the idea of sacrificing personal conveniences in order to save the planet, and it goes so far as to compare reliance on fossil fuels ("black dinosaur juice") to an addiction. Lyric snippets: "Well, he traded in his dumb ol' Ford / For a new smart car with an extension cord / Now he’s saving gas and got a cheaper note / But he’s got no way to haul his boat / It’s the little things we take for granted / When we sacrifice to save the planet / Darndest thing I’ve ever seen / That old redneck has done gone green / Down the road, old man McGower / You know he runs his house on the solar power / Now his lights are bright and the music plays / Sorta dark and quiet on the cloudy days ... / The life we knew is coming to a halt / ’S sad but true and it’s our own fault / We put our own crimson necks right in the noose / We got strung out on that black dinosaur juice" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "earth moment" by Sirintip is included in the database for lyrics that construct a personal call to action to specifically address climate change, based on implicit lyrical references and explicit background information about the album "carbon." The opening verse and first chorus reflect on personal responsibility to take action: "you can tell me i’m lost / that it’s a hopeless cause / you can tell me, there’s no use / that i should move on with my life / but i refuse, to look the other way / i know too much, to turn blind and say / it’s all ok, there’s more we need to do than pray" (Bandcamp). The song closes with the line "better use my voice, can't be silent," illustrating that Sirintip is using her music for climate activism (Bandcamp). Although climate change is not explicitly referenced in this particular song, the context surrounding the album "carbon" clearly illustrates that this personal call to action is about climate change. The album notes for "carbon" indicate that the album is inspired by "three years of climate research and patient self-discovery" and aims to "appeal for a new kind of conversation around climate action" (Bandcamp).

works.notes: Randy Newman's "The Great Debate," a humorous and complex multi-part song depicting religious and secular arguments on issues ranging from the cosmos to evolution, is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. At one point during the arguments from the song's cast of characters, a question is posed about global warming: "Next question: global warming. Is it, and if so, so what— One of the true believers seeks to be recognized. Hand him a mic, Charles. Thank you" (Genius Lyrics). A religious man speaks up, saying "I, myself, believe in Jesus. I believe in evolution, also. I believe in global warming, and in life everlasting. No one can knock me down" (Genius Lyrics).

works.work_title: All The Good Girls Go To Hell
works.notes: "All The Good Girls Go To Hell" is included for the music video's context and for specific lyrical references to California wildfires and rising sea levels, together forming a strong implicit reference to climate change. Additionally, the music video shows Eilish falling from the sky with angel wings into a tar pit, alluding to fossil fuels. The video posted on YouTube by her official channel includes the hashtag #climatestrike, tying the song specifically to climate activism. Lyric snippet: "Hills burn in California / My turn to ignore ya / Don't say I didn't warn ya / All the good girls go to Hell / 'Cause even God herself has enemies / And once the water starts to rise / And Heaven's out of sight / She'll want the Devil on her team" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "When The North Pole Melts" by Captain Sea Level, "The Balladeer of the Climate Community," is a comedic Christmas song that explicitly refers to global warming and polar ice melt in its lyrics. Lyric Snippets: "Want to tell you 'bout the greenhouse effect and a little ozone hole / That started out over Antarctica, but has now spread to the North Pole / You will soon see every warm-weather man / At the Jersey Shore in March... But if you don't believe this warning / 'Bout the climate and the ozone hole / Look under your tree one Christmas morning / All you'll see are lumps of coal" (song.risingsea.net). The song was performed live at the Climate Institute's conference in December 1988 in Washington, DC with the Environmental Protection Agency chorus (song.risingsea.net, climate.org archive). A live recording has not been found but a self-released studio recording and a lyric/chord sheet is available for download at song.risingsea.net.

works.notes: "Climate Change" by GAWVI is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change in the song title and in the lyrics. According to a mini-documentary about the album "Heathen," GAWVI wrote many of the songs on the album to challenge ideas about the word "heathen" in Christian culture (YouTube). In this context, many uses of the phrase "climate change" in the song refer to a change in culture or understanding rather than the scientific meaning. However, "climate change" is used in a few specific places that imply double meaning encompassing the scientific meaning as well: "I feel the flames, known from the climate change, who run it?" (Genius Lyrics). Flames here could be a reference to Hell in Christianity, or heat and/or wildfires caused by climate change, or perhaps both. Furthermore, GAWVI says "Climate change not my fault," implying an idea of lack of individual responsibility for some bigger phenomenon (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Melissa Etheridge's "I Need to Wake Up" is included in the database for it's association with the 2006 documentary "An Inconvenient Truth" about global warming. Etheridge wrote the song for the documentary, including the lyrics "Now I am throwing off the carelessness of youth / To listen to an inconvenient truth," which explicitly references the documentary. The chorus does not reference climate change specifically, but it creates a call to action in the context of the film: "That I need to move / I need to wake up / I need to change / I need to shake up / I need to speak out / Something’s got to break up / I’ve been asleep / And I need to wake up / Now" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Shut It Down" by Pitbull featuring Akon is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. In the second verse, Pitbull raps the lines "I don't make it rain / I speak that global warming," connecting the idea of a lack of rain in a hotter climate to the literal meaning of the expression "make it rain," which figuratively refers to the act of generously giving away money (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Truth To Power" was recorded by OneRepublic for the 2017 climate documentary "An Inconvenient Sequel," which narrates Al Gore's continuing efforts to educate the public about climate change and take action (notably including footage from the Paris Climate Negotiations in 2016) (Wikipedia). The song's lyrics are vague, but the title and chorus reference the documentary title and the lyric video posted on YouTube by OneRepublic includes footage of earth from space, melting ice, climate change protests, and victims of natural disasters. Lyric snippets: "Minutes turn to hours / Hours turn to years / And I've seen truth turn to power... Dust don't turn to flowers / Skies don't disappear / But I've seen truth turn to power" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Parts per Million" by Rise Against is included in the database for an explicit lyrical reference to global warming combined with a titular reference to the unit of measurement commonly used for the atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gases, parts per million. The song's opening verse explicitly mentions rising temperatures in the context of ignoring warnings of disaster: "There's something wrong and the temperature is risin' / Ignoring every siren / As we're marching towards the cliff" (Genius Lyrics). Additionally, carbon dioxide, a significant greenhouse gas, is frequently measured using the molecular ratio of "Parts per Million," as seen on graphs of atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration measured at the Mauna Loa Observatory (NASA).

works.notes: Smash Mouth's hit "All Star" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change in the second verse and confirmation of relationship to climate change in an interview with the songwriter. In the second verse of the lyrics, songwriter Greg Camp mentions ice getting thinner, water getting warmer, and a world "on fire:" "The ice we skate is getting pretty thin / The water's getting warm so you might as well swim / My world's on fire, how 'bout yours? / That's the way I like it and I'll never get bored" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Greg Camp confirmed in an interview with the New York Times (See The Climate 'Hot 10 Songs') that the lyrics form a reference to climate change.

works.notes:
"A Minute to Breathe" is included in the database for the context of the 2016 climate change documentary "Before the Flood" and for lyrics anticipating a great flood that humans are to blame for. The song was composed for the film by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross. The documentary draws a connection between climate change and the Bosch painting "The Garden of Earthly Delights," depicting a three-part transformation of paradise to destruction, with the second panel of the painting entitled "Before the Flood" (Wikipedia). The song reflects the idea that destruction is coming and that humans are responsible for it: "We wait / We pray / For the rain / For the rain / For a rain / To wash away / We try / Deny / To believe / To believe / We can't believe / In anything / I don't want to say goodbye / Stars falling from the sky / We will all be judged
By what we leave behind" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: Radiohead's "Idioteque" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The lyrics present an impending crisis with divided opinions on whether or not the crisis is real. The second verse makes a reference to discourse about climate change: "Ice Age coming, Ice Age coming / Let me hear both sides, let me hear both sides, let me hear both / Ice Age coming, Ice Age coming / Throw him in the fire, throw him in the fire, throw him on the / We're not scaremongering / This is really happening, happening / We're not scaremongering / This is really happening, happening / Mobiles skwerking, mobiles chirping / Take the money and run, take the money and run, take the money" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). When considered in the context of Radiohead's climate activism and interests (Thom Yorke was reading Worldwatch Institute statistics about climate change while recording Kid A), the call to "hear both sides" and accusations of "scaremongering" reflect specific, well-documented tactics used by people interested in delaying action on climate change (Wikipedia, PNAS).

works.notes: "Punch Drunk Grinning Soul" by Flogging Molly is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. In the song's second verse, frontman Dave King sings these somber and reflective lyrics: "The chamber echo never speaks, the rushing tide devours my feet / No global warming fills this soul, for hell it freezes what it stole / From the beggar's empty plate / To our world that stuffs its face" (Genius Lyrics). Global warming in the context notably indicates an idea of warmth that is contrasted with the coldness of hell freezing.

works.notes: "The Substance" by Aesop Rock is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. The song alludes to a variety of themes, including mental health and thirst/starvation, and the explicit reference occurs in a verse about hunger and thirst occurring throughout changing seasons: "In the summer it rains buckets of hunger pains / In the winter it's the same, with an added climate change / The remaining two quadrants balance the polar values equally for mid-range / Yet the songs of thirst remain the same"(Genius Lyrics). Here, Aesop Rock refers to climate change but uses it to represent the change in seasonal weather rather than its definition (changes in weather patterns over long time scales). Aesop rock also uses the word "climate" two other times in the song, creating a motif: "With what I sing, I'll open lash light and dark clash to dim the wattage / Then see the wide-eyed dried raising supplied fiery Colossus / Well, I am a hostage, guiding, yet, pushed beneath the craze's climate / Hiding behind the levy while the stubborn rivers rise and feel this ... I'm a sideline observer alerted not yet retreating / (Close to insanity) / The climate stubbornly hovered slightly above freezing / (Close to insanity) / Now everybody in the populace awaited my reply / (Close to insanity) / I spit a billion tiny brilliant white lights into the sky / (Close to insanity)" (Genius Lyrics). Weather events, including the rising of a river against a levy, are frequently used as metaphors throughout the song.

works.notes: "Some More" by Juice WRLD is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. This unreleased song, which was produced by Chopsquad DJ according to Genius Lyrics, includes the following lyrics: "Got the heater on my hip like global warming, ayy / Run up, you get shot, this is a warnin'" (Genius Lyrics). Here, Juice WRLD connects heat generated by firing a gun (known as a heater in old time gangster slang) to the rise in temperatures associated with global warming.

Anvil's "Gasoline" is included in the database for a very strong implicit reference to climate change and its connection to the burning of fossil fuels. The song discusses the environmental damage caused by and the political importance of gasoline. This fossil fuel is often combusted in automobile engines, releasing carbon dioxide (a greenhouse gas) into the atmosphere (Wikipedia). In the third verse, Anvil sings: "Alternative options / The way to forge ahead / Renewable energy / It's already been said / Environmental damage / The cost to humanity / Will there ever be justice / Or some sanity?" (Genius Lyrics). Here, the "environmental damage" and "cost to humanity" clearly at least partially imply climate change, considering that alternative energy ("Alternative options / The way to forge ahead") differs from fossil fuels in that it offers a way to generate electricity without emitting greenhouse gas emissions that exacerbate climate change (Wikipedia).

works.notes: "Fuck This Election" by Tyler, the Creator is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. The song expresses negative and demeaning attitudes towards candidates in the 2008 United States presidential election. The global warming-themed lyrics are used to deliver a sexist and sexually explicit insult to Republican vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin, who, among other conservative positions, has publicly expressed skepticism in the science underpinning global warming and has supported the oil industry while serving as governor of the state of Alaska (Wikipedia). Lyric snippet: "She from Alaska, I roll down south / Pull my penguin out and put that global warming in her mouth" (Genius Lyrics).

However, the second verse not only mentions global warming directly, but also makes a passing reference to sea level rise: "Global warming, rising up / Devil's at sea level now / Just walking around like a free man / And no one gives a fuck" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Attack of the Clones" by Jay Electronica is included in the database for explicitly referencing US politician Al Gore's global warming campaign, which was the topic of the 2006 documentary "An Inconvenient Truth" (Wikipedia). Lyrics snippet: "The kid intends to split more wigs than British Parliament / Catch me on the global warming tour with Jigga and Al Gore / Performing "Dear Summer", where Autumn went? / Eternal Sunshine, drum major without a drumline" (Genius Lyrics). The lyrics connect the idea of global warming to the Jay-Z song "Dear Summer" and pose a question to the audience about the disappearance of the autumn season, perhaps due to the referenced warming (Genius Lyrics). The lyrics also connect global warming to "eternal sunshine," referring to his album "Act I: The Eternal Sunshine (The Pledge)" (Genius Lyrics). Jay Electronica also notably performed these lyrics as a freestyle at the Rock The Bells Music Festival in 2008 (YouTube).

works.notes: B.o.B's "Flatline," which endorses numerous debunked conspiracy theories including the flat earth theory, is included in the database for a sample of astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson discussing the shape of the globe that briefly mentions global warming and melting ice caps. This song was released as a diss track aimed at Tyson after Tyson debunked B.o.B's statements on Twitter in support of the flat earth theory (YouTube, Genius). The relevant part of the sample includes the following sentences: "And it turns out sea level at the equator is farther away from the center of the Earth than sea level near the poles. It has nothing to do with global warming and melting of the ice caps" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "I Feed These Streets" by B.o.B is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. In the second verse, B.o.B describes a scene where he is a dungeon, partially exposed to the elements, including seasonal extremes: "I welcome you into my mind state / Now follow me back into the dungeon that's where I would lay / With no doors, no windows just a fire place / So hot summers, cold winters as the climate change / I used to roll with savages and primates" (Genius Lyrics). In this context, B.o.B may just be referring to the change in temperature between seasons rather than the change in the climate, but he was particular about using the phrase "climate change" in the rhyme, rather than saying "as the climate changes" or "as the weather changes" or any number of other ways to express a seasonal change in temperature. This specific choice of phrase, accompanied by a momentary drop in the volume of the backing track and B.o.B yelling "Ha!" right after "that's the climate change," is almost certainly a recognizable reference to most audiences.

works.notes: "If a Tree Falls" is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change caused by deforestation and emissions from agriculture. He goes on to mention methane, a greenhouse gas, explicitly in the second verse, connecting deforestation to agriculture: "Take out wildlife at a rate of species every single day / Take out people who've lived with this / For a hundred thousand years— / Inject a billion burgers worth of beef— / Grain eaters—methane dispensers" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Vessel" by SheisArjuna is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to global warming in the lyrics and additional context provided by the artist tying the song to climate change. The lyrics, which convey SheisArjuna's intention to "use my voice like a vessel" in order to participate in a conversation about protecting the planet, open with the lines "Temperatures' rising / The conversation's not hiding anymore" (Genius Lyrics). The song was nominated for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize, and on the song's entry page, SheisArjuna says the following about the meaning of the song: "The song was inspired by climate change and my role as an artist to bring attention to environmental issues through music. It is about being a vessel for positive change; I care deeply about protecting biodiversity and feel it is so important to offer these messages through palatable, mainstream music in order to have a wider impact. As a Conservation and Wildlife Biology graduate, I’m passionate on a personal level to reduce my environmental footprint as much as possible. We each have a role in ensuring we can continue on as a species. Music has been a beautiful way to share my message and my passions" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: "Beds Are Burning (Dry Riverbed Version)" is included in the database for explicit references to climate change and for its use in a climate change-focused campaign led by the Global Humanitarian Forum in 2009. The song, which features many musicians and celebrities covering the original song by Australian rock band Midnight Oil, opens with a narrated segment by former United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan: "Climate change is having a real impact on the lives of individuals and communities around the world. We must do something about it. In December in Copenhagen, our leaders will have an opportunity to come up with a robust post-climate agreement that is viable and will help make this planet a better place" (Genius Lyrics). The song ends with a narrated segment by Desmond Tutu: "I support the Campaign For Climate Justice and I'm pleased to become a climate ally. This is your campaign" (Genius Lyrics). In addition to the narrated segments, the song refers to warming and agricultural failures and calls the listener to action: "Down at the river bed / The earth is cracked and dry instead / Farms are failing, cities baking / Steam in 45 degrees / The time has come / To take a stand / It's for the Earth / It's for our land / The time has come / A fact's a fact / The heat is on / No turning back" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes:
"Time For A Change" by The Jade Assembly is included in the database for context surrounding the song, including confirmation by the band's manager Mick Watson that the song is written about climate change. The song's lyrics include general criticism of government and a call to action to avert a preventable disaster: "So throw away your brain today and let your government dictate / I’m standing here for everyone who’s never too afraid to say / The time to look ahead is now the time before we’re all dead / Come on / Because it’s time for a change" (audio track). The song does not make a reference to climate change itself, but the band's manager Mick Watson was quoted in both Express and Metro UK confirming the song's relevance to climate change. In a Metro UK article published on November 11th, 2019, Watson was quoted saying "The Jade Assembly have always been passionate about the climate crisis and they penned this song out of frustration with the speed and the way our politicians dealt with the crisis" (metro.co.uk). In an Express article published on November 14th, 2019, Watson was quoted saying "The song was written about climate change" (express.co.uk). The music video for the song features footage from protest by climate change activist group Extinction Rebellion (YouTube). It should be noted that information in these articles claim that a campaign to get the song to the No. 1 position in the UK for Christmas in 2019 was a planned collaboration between Extinction Rebellion and The Jade Assembly, but this has been challenged. The official Extinction Rebellion statement released on November 14th, 2019 states that while "Extinction Rebellion UK would like to thank The Jade Assembly for their support and wish them well in the charts," that "there isn’t an ‘official’ campaign to get an XR ‘anthem’ to number one, as Extinction Rebellion doesn’t ‘team
up’ or partner in this way" (Extinction Rebellion).

works.notes: "Greenpeace" by James is included in the database for environmentally-themed lyrics combined with a song title that refers to Greenpeace, a notable organization that advocates for action on climate change (Wikipedia). The lyrics include perspectives of an apathetic citizen ("I don't like the world I see / So I'll avert my gaze to the T.V / I'm too cool to get involved / Someone else can change the channel for me"), a businessperson ("Gonna suck the juices out of this world / Gonna treat her rough it's all she deserves / She's so cold to me / Gonna rape this world with my straight lines / Gonna straighten her out 'cause nature is just history"), and the earth herself reacting to the damage being caused to her ("There's a hole in my heart / Your so cruel to me / There's a hole in my heart / From your industry / There's a hole in my heart") (Genius Lyrics). The title's explicit reference to a climate activist organization adds context to the lyrics indicating that one of the impacts humans are having on the earth is climate change.

works.notes: "Golden Chains" by Hazel Mei is included in the database for context provided by the artist definitely linking the song to climate change. The reveals a bleak outlook on the future of humankind that implies destruction at our own hands. The chorus repeats the lines "I don't wanna die in golden chains / Crying over loss of golden reigns," and other lyrics further tie the song to consumption, wealth, and economic activity: "But all they do is bury / Our future in their hands / 'Cause all they want is growing / The money they can spend" (Bandcamp). The song's theme is climate change according to Mei, who wrote "My climate change anthem <3" in the description on Bandcamp. The song was nominated for the Environmental Music Prize in 2023, and on the song's entry page, Mei says the following about why she wrote the song: "The consequences of climate change terrify me. It consumed my mind as I entered adulthood, and I knew I needed to be part of the solution. I read information, watched documentaries, wrote to MPs, attended protests, and reshaped my lifestyle. I was hopeful during the “climate election” of 2019, but felt devastated at the results. It showed me how much work still needed to be done to protect our collective future. My environment-focused echo chamber cast a shadow on the majority, who appeared to prefer short-term economic gain over long-term conservation. I felt helpless for a while before being re-motivated by AURORA and her use of music to inspire and educate. I had previously written songs about important issues but felt too insecure about sharing them. Now, that mindset has changed, inspiring ‘Golden Chains.'" Keeping with this theme, the music video shows Mei fearfully treading water as it rises above her neck, which may form a reference to sea level rise, a consequence of climate change (YouTube).

works.notes: "1.5" is the sixth track on Sirintip's "carbon," included in the database for an explicit titular reference to global warming and for album notes that confirm this reference. Album notes for "carbon" include this statement: "1.5" expresses the planet’s steady ongoing rise in temperature, pulling NASA data from 1880 through 2012 (Bandcamp). Additionally, 1.5 degrees of warming above pre-industrial levels is a frequently cited number in discussions of climate policy, particularly at the international level (IPCC). The song itself includes looped vocal melodies and does not have lyrics, but the context provided by the title of the song, the album title, and connection to climate change listed in album notes forms a clear and explicit reference to climate change.

works.notes: "Earth" by Dweezil Zappa is included in the database for a strong and consistent pro-environmental message that includes explicit references to global warming and the greenhouse effect. In the song's bridge, an extended section of recorded samples discuss many environmental issues, including global warming: "80 percent of the land vegetation on Earth is located in the rainforests of Central and South America...making them vital both to our oxygen supply and to counteract the atmospheric buildup of Carbon Dioxide... Hey don't worry about it...GREENHOUSE EFFECT!!! Global Warming...SUPPORT GREENPEACE...POLLUTION..." (Genius lyrics). This section notably references the greenhouse effect, carbon emissions, global warming, and the climate activist group Greenpeace. The chorus of the song urges the listener to take action on behalf of the earth: "I can see quite clearly that the Earth's in distress / We're killing our own planet it's time we all protest / I can see quite clearly that the Earth's in distress / We are all responsible...it's time to show respect" (Genius lyrics).

works.notes: Ministry's "Alert Level" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song contains samples of climate activist Greta Thunberg's speech at the UN Climate Action summit in 2019, which, combined with a pessimistic lyrical message about death and doom and "the end of the world" at our own hands, clearly evokes the destruction caused by the climate crisis. Amidst other samples, Greta Thunberg can clearly be heard saying "Young people are starting to understand your betrayal" and "We will not let you get away with this," both directly cut from a recording of the 2019 UN speech (Genius lyrics, NPR). The rest of the song's lyrics adhere to a similar tone of anger and condemnation: "The cards on the table / The hands are on deck / Heading to a future / We all reject / Let's get ready / Let's get ready / Let's get ready / Get ready to die / This is a shame / This is immoral / There's no one to blame / But ourselves" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "End Of The World" by Sunfruits is included in the database for context provided by the artist explaining the song's connection to climate change. The song was nominated for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize, and on the song's entry page, the artists' description of the song confirms that the repeated lyric "the very first year of the apocalypse" is a reference to the 2020 Australian bush fires (known as the Black Summer of 2020), which were exacerbated by climate change (Environmental Music Prize, Wikipedia). The artists say about the track, "We were really inspired by the general theme of love and light during darkness – or love during a pandemic and climate crisis" and the music video includes imagery of a frantic weatherman and small globe burning up in flames, further strengthening the song's tie to the climate. The title of the album this track belongs to is "One Degree," making a clear reference to the amount of global warming that has occurred since the industrial revolution (1 degree Celsius) (climate.gov). Merch for the album includes an image of a small thermometer reading 1 degree Celsius, enforcing the reference to the temperature.

works.notes: "Warrior" by Meraki Mae is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change and additional context provided by the artist and contained in the music video. "The sea's slowly rising and we're slowly dying / Underneath the red hot sun" forms a clear reference to climate change, specifically warming and sea-level rise, in the context of the song's call to action. The song was chosen as a finalist for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize. On the song's entry web page, Mae describes inspiration for the song coming from the people of Lismore, New South Wales, for climate activism and resilience in the face of disasters including major floods: "I have watched the way that this vibrant town has been torn apart, and risen in the face of adversity, supporting one another through climate grief, disaster, loss and struggle, to demand change and justice. This passion, this leadership, this deep connection and care, and the hope it represented, is what drove me to write this song ‘Warrior’. It is a song I dedicate to the First Nations voices that drive our fight for a better future, by acknowledging the past. It is a song for us all, to remind us that the earth is our home, to care for and protect. It is a song aimed to empower and to remind us that together, we are capable of great change" (Environmental Music Prize). The song's music video includes news clips of the Lismore Floods and a fracking protest documentary. According to Mae, "I wanted the film clip to address the climate catastrophe of the floods but more than that I wanted to show that our community is resilient, strong and will not be ignored, just like we were not ignored at the Bentley Blockade in 2013/14. I wanted to show that it is our ability to love and support each other in the face of adversity that makes us warriors. That together we have the strength to create change" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: GWAR's song "Swarm" is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. "Swarm" is a typical example of GWAR's signature songwriting style, which combines thrash metal with satirical and often cras, who a lyrics telling a fictional story about the band members, who are barbaric interplanetary warriors. In the context of "Swarm," GWAR has created the human race and is now condemning the human tendency to consume resources and procreate, or "swarm" like insects. In this context, GWAR satirically downplays global warming compared to what they view as a population problem: "You've been misinformed, my dear / The global ill that you should fear / Is not global warming / Stop global swarming!" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Global Warming" by John Grant is included the database for numerous explicit references to climate change, including in the title, lyrics, and music video. The title of the song alone is grounds for inclusion, but the song's lyrics include the phrase "global warming" twice in each chorus, reflecting cynically on negative impacts of sun exposure, the destruction of rainforests in Brazil, and the relationship between heat waves and the rates of urban violence: "Global warming is ruining my fair complexion / Augmenting all my imperfections / And Brazil does not need more encouragement / Global warming encourages slack jawed troglodytes / To leave their homes with guns and knives / In search of bodily refreshments and some homicide" (Genius Lyrics). The music video for the song portrays Grant as a lonely survivor in warmed world, in the middle of a partially destroyed home full of melted plastic items, sifting through and watching old physical media like CDs and DVDs and drinking his own sweat squeezed out of his socks (YouTube).

works.notes: "unspoken gold" by Sirintip is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming due to the usage of fossil fuels. The lyrics describe a conflict with fossil fuels from the perspective of earth, specifically referring to the consumption of fuel and warmer conditions: "oh black hole / unspoken gold / let me out of your control / down to the depths of earth for you / warmer conditions low on fuel / exhausted my youth / it's all been used" (Bandcamp). The song represents a transition from fossil fuels to wind energy according to the Bandcamp track notes: "Unspoken gold is about the cleaning process of turning fossil fuel into clean renewable wind energy" (Bandcamp).

works.notes: "Illusions" is included in the database for context surrounding the song tying it to climate change. Wojtek's album "Atmosphere," which contains the track "Illusions," was recorded with climate change in mind on several levels, referring to the earth's atmosphere in title and using carbon neutral processes (iamwojtek.com). According to Wojtek's website, the album was promoted using a video for Wojtek's song "Illusions," made with repurposed video clips, emitting 0.081 kg carbon dioxide through the energy used to edit the video, and hosted on web servers using renewable energy (iamwojtek.com). Wojtek's attention to the greenhouse gas emissions of his music, and of the "Illusions" promotional video, ties the song specifically to climate change.

works.notes:
"Backburner" by Wildheart is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change and for comments provided by the artist linking the song to climate change in the context of Australia's 2020 bushfires. The lyrics, which express righteous anger at authorities for their role in environmental destruction at the expense of indigenous people, make references to sea level rise and increased wildfires, both caused by climate change: "The oceans rise / The forests burn
/ The earth shakes / It's screaming out for blood / You can't try to put us on the back burner / This was not something that we could foresee / What will it take for you to wake up" (YouTube). The song was a finalist in the 2023 Environmental Music Prize, and on the the song's entry page, the band wrote the following about the music video, tying it explicitly to climate change: "The concept behind this music video first came about when the lyrics for the single ‘Backburner’ were written. We wanted to work with our videographer on a concept that was thought provoking around climate change and the immediate threat of the Australian bushfires we were facing, and one that also captured the ferocity of our live performance and Axel’s Connection to Country. Thomas E.S. Kelly who performs in the music video is a Proud Minjunbal-Yugambeh man with a strong connection to the Gold Coast area... ‘Backburner’ also features powerful words from Indigenous Elder Bruce Shillingsworth from ABC’s Q&A program in October 2019 when he called for Australia to “wake up”" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: "Moral Panic" by Nothing But Thieves is included in the database for a strong implicit lyrical reference to climate change and for additional context provided by the artist in interviews linking the song to climate change. The song's opening verse likely paraphrases from a 2019 speech given to European Parliament by youth climate activist Greta Thunberg. In the speech, which was given on April 16th, 2019 in front of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, Thunberg urged political leaders to take action on climate change, saying "Well, our house is falling apart, and we are rapidly running out of time. And yet, basically nothing is happening. Everyone and everything needs to change" (Archives of Women's Political Communication). The song appears to quote one of the lines from this speech and refer to Thunberg: "This is the last day of my life, yours too / Haven't you ever seen the ocean look so blue? / "And now we're running out of time", she said / All of the children are so anxious, they're on edge / Yeah, it's tense, so tense" (Genius Lyrics). Furthermore, the lyrics use imagery of burning to describe what is happening to the earth, further developing the theme around climate change by possibly alluding to forest fires or high temperatures and emphasizing that humanity is complicit in the destruction: "Now, the earth, it turns so slow / Strike up a match and we let it go / Now, the earth, it burns so slow / A million faces in a row / We're standing back and we watch it go / And we let it go / And we let it go / And we let it" (Genius Lyrics). In an interview with Maria Bocci for music critic website The Line of Best Fit, lead guitarist and vocalist confirmed the song's connection to climate change, saying "It’s kind of this pessimistic, dark, Simon and Garfunkel song about the end of the world and about climate change which has this infectious kind of dance groove to it, but it’s quite sad and emotionally sung I think" (The Line of Best Fit).

works.notes: "Another Way to Die" is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change, specifically glacier ice melting due to global warming. The song questions the ability of humanity to survive while destroying the environment, referencing species loss, air pollution and glaciers melting. The song creates a sense of urgency around acting to address the damage in time: "Consequences we cannot deny / Will be revealed in time / Glaciers melt as we pollute the sky / A sign of devastation coming / We don’t need another way to die / Can we repent in time?" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). The music video prominently focuses on fossil fuel infrastructure, adding another layer to the commentary on global warming (YouTube).

works.notes: "Won't Give Up" by Pattie Gonie featuring Yo-Yo Ma and Quinn Christopherson is included in the database for context surrounding the song, including confirmation by the artists that it was written as an anthem for climate change activism. The song's music video was filmed near Exit Glacier glacier in Kenai Fjords National Park, which shows the glacier before and after significant melting due to climate change (NPR). "There's a lot of potential for this song to be sung at climate rallies, to be sung as a part of the climate movement," said Gonia, as quoted in an NPR article about the song published on November 13th, 2023 (NPR). While the lyrics do not refer to climate change in explicit terms, they offer a call to action in the midst of a great challenge ("I won't give up for a minute / Never giving up on you"), an appeal to unity ("You & I / Made up of the same things / Nature running in our veins"), and a couple of potential global warming references: "Well we’re caught / Caught up in the fire of time ... I saw you burning / Up in the night" (YouTube). Gonia acknowledges that the song is intentionally vague and may relate to people fighting for other causes, such as LGBTQ+ right, saying "If a person hears it and thinks that it's not about climate but that it's about racial justice or that it's about queer rights, that's beautiful. Take it, go for it" (NPR).

works.notes: "When Tomorrow Comes" by Scorpions is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. The song broadly reflects on environmental damage in a conversation between the singer and the earth, referencing pollution, fires, and climate change. Lyric snippet: "Good morning world / How do you feel? / You look so sad / The clock is ticking / And precious time will fade away / Oh, the cyber war / A dirty ocean, the climate change / When tomorrow comes we'll pay the price / For today" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Childish Gambino's "Feels Like Summer" is included in the database for references to rising temperatures, the population of earth, technological progress, species loss, and the need for change, together forming a strong implicit reference to climate change. The lyric "Every day gets hotter than the one before" is the clearest indicator of global warming, and the line "Men who made machines that want what they decide," followed by a plea to "slow down," indicates human responsibility and the need for action (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Gambino also refers to "Seven billion souls that move around the sun," as well as the loss of birds and bees, indicating risks to earth and its inhabitants, both human and non-human.

works.notes: "Not in California" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change as one of the contributing factors to California wildfires and reflections on the costs on inaction on the climate. A reference to power lines strongly suggests the 2019 Camp Fire in Paradise, California, which occurred earlier in the year the song was released. Lyric snippets: "The birds all died and the trees caught fire / And the government, it called us crazy / We built a big world, then we watched it all burn / 'Cause the television made us lazy / It didn't seem true when the power lines blew / Yeah, the heroin, it made us hazy / I looked up at the clouds as I was freakin' out / God save me" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Gentle" by Georgia Mae was included in the database for strong implicit references to climate change and context provided by the artists tying the song directly to the issue. The song's reflective lyrics imagine life 10,000 years ago before human activity affected the natural world and implore the listener to be "a bit more Gentle" to mother earth. In the second verse, Mae directly mentions ice melting, loss of ocean biodiversity, and deforestation: "Grew up thinking how much I  / Can’t wait to see the coral reefs, And the Amazon, and the glaciers and a million more. / But now that’s turning into a pipe dream, How can it be, it’s not that we can’t see, So why we doing nothing?" (YouTube video description). "Gentle" was nominated for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize. In her own words: "Writing this song was therapy! I’d been wanting to express my anxiety about the impacts of climate change on mother earth for so long, but could never really find the right words to put in a pop song" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: Lake Street Dive's "Making Do" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. According to the band's Instagram post announcing the song and linking to the music video, the song "is about the world that future generations are inheriting. We are all concerned about what is happening to our planet, so the song explores what arises when we consider both our role in it and our responsibility to address it" (Instagram). This alone does not tie the song to climate change specifically, but the lyrics refer to a world that has warmed enough to affect agriculture and prevent Kenya and Colombia from being able to grow coffee: "To the next generation, merry Christmas / You're working harder than ever now and the coffee sucks / You know Colombia and Kenya got too damn hot / And now you're making do with what you've got" (Genius Lyrics). Beyond this clear reference to global warming, the lyrics also refer to storm surge and storm frequency, both associated with climate change: "Killer waves and riots / Coming to the coastline soon / Counting up the new typhoons / Quicker than kilowatts / How could you deny it?" (Genius Lyrics). The song was discussed in the podcast "Degrees," season 3, episode 1, "Lake Street Dive on music, activism, and bravery" (Spotify).

works.notes: Anya Anastasia's "Losing Wild," a reflection on the loss of wildlife, is included in the database for context provided by the artist connecting the song to biodiversity loss caused by climate change. The song's lyrics lament the disappearance of many species, using imagery of a dry, barren desert: "The hourglass drains there’s no Noah’s Ark in the desert / So they’re going away / Only time rains down on this bleak parade in the desert / The Twilight of Wilder Days" (YouTube). The song was a finalist for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize, and on the song's web page, Anastasia ties the song's inspiration to climate change: "In Losing Wild, I explore how the loss of biodiversity diminishes human imagination. The song suggests that the extinction crisis not only poses heartbreaking and planet-threatening external risks, but also heralds the end of good poetry and diminishment of playful minds. We need to listen to our scientists, and to find solutions we also all need to engage our imaginations. We are already feeling the effects of anthropogenic climate change. We know now that without decisive, urgent and widespread changes there are frightening climate tipping points on our horizon that could trigger cascades of further catastrophic effects. To turn things around we need to spark social tipping points mobilising a population to demand systemic change. To do this I believe we need the full engagement and commitment of creative minds, and our artistic community" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: Anti Flag's "LAUGH. CRY. SMILE. DIE." is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to global warming. The second verse makes a reference to a corporate memo in the 1980s: "Flashback to 1983 / Emphasize the uncertainty / The memo says the company / Turns truth into a theory" (Genius Lyrics). While this verse does not explicitly mention global warming, it contains enough context to be directly linked to Inside Climate News reporting in 2015 documenting oil company Exxon Mobil's internal knowledge of the warming effect of greenhouse gas emissions in internal reports and presentations from 1982 (Inside Climate News). Exxon would later dedicate resources to promoting climate change skepticism (to "Emphasize the uncertainty" in climate models) despite its internal knowledge of the relationship between emissions and warming (Assessing ExxonMobil's climate change communications).

works.notes: "MAISON" by Dreamcatcher is included in the database for a strong implicit lyrical reference to climate change and context provided by the artist in interviews. The lyrics clearly describe an environmental disaster caused by humans using a mixture of English, Korean and French. A reference to rising temperatures strongly suggests global warming: "You want the easy way, you'll get hurt (Be my side) / Isn't it strangely hot? / The laws of this planet, so dry / Just like your conscience (Hoo)" (Dami's verse, Genius Lyrics translation from Korean to English). The song's chorus begs the listener to protect "la maison," which is French for "the home," a clear reference to the Earth: "Save my home in the jungle / Save my home in the polar / (La, maison la-la-la, maison) / Save my home in the ocean / Save my home in the desert / (La, maison) / Please, someone fight for us" (Genius lyrics). In an interview with Rolling Stone India, band members Handong and Yoohyeon stated that “The message of the track is that we need to raise awareness about environmental damages, pollution, and global warming” (Rolling Stone India).

works.notes: King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard's "If Not Now, Then When?" is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change that clearly illuminate the song title as a call to environmental action, including on the issue of climate. Furthermore, songwriter Stu Mackenzie confirmed the song's connection to climate change. In the first verse, three lines connected to climate change are grouped together: "When the ocean's coming up / When the rain just won't stop / When the fire's burning / If not now, then when?" (Genius Lyrics). While not naming climate change explicitly, this verse makes very clear references to the issues of sea level rise, changing rainfall patterns, and increased wildfires, all of which are consequences of climate change. "If Not Now, Then When?" was a 2022 finalist for the Environmental Music Prize, and songwriter Stu Mackenzie wrote the following on the entry's webpage: "I’ve written quite a few songs about climate change, but after the black summer bushfires in 2019-2020, shit started to feel dire. It still feels dire – more dire. We need actual, real, tangible action from our leaders, otherwise what are they there for? Why are we not doing everything we humanly can to right our wrongs? When we’re literally on fire, why not now? If not now, then when?" (environmentalmusicprize.com).

works.notes: "Climate Change," the song that opens Act II of Starkid Productions' comedy musical "Firebringer", is included in the database for its title and for clear allegorical and comedic references to global warming in the lyrics of the song and in the dialogue following the song. This song was performed by Lauren Lopez and the original cast. The musical follows a tribe of prehistoric humans as they discover and react to fire for the first time, and the song "climate change" illustrates how the humans have changed their lifestyle using this new tool to eat animals instead of hunting and gathering: "Huh, that's right, just do whatever you want / There's been a change in the climate / Something's in the air / I feel the heat / No need to define it (need to define it) / We don't really care (Ahh...) / Come on, let's eat now / There's more food than we can eat in a lifetime / No need to share / No, baby, it's all mine" (Genius Lyrics). The reference to global warming is made very clear in a joke delivered to the audience, breaking the fourth wall, by the character Zazzalil, who says "I believe that if we burn enough things, we can change the climate permanently" (YouTube). In this context, the song makes a comparison between the technological development of fire in prehistoric times and the consumption of fossil fuels in modern times.
