works.notes: While "New World Water" mainly focuses on the politics and consequences of water scarcity, it includes several implicit references to consequences of climate change tied to water. The opening lines "New World Water make the tide rise high / Come inland and make your house go 'Bye'" reference the impacts of high tide storm surge on human infrastructure, a consequence of rising sea levels and increased storm frequency caused by climate change. At the end of the first verse, the lines "The Sun is sitting in the treetops, burnin' the woods / And as the flames from the blaze get higher and higher / They say 'Don't drink the water, we need it for the fire!'" demonstrate the connection between water scarcity and wildfires, another phenomenon contributing to and exacerbated by climate change (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Waiting For The Tide" by Cody Simpson & The Tide is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change through sea level rise. The first verse describes humanity waiting for imminent sea level rise but unable to respond, with feet "stuck in quicksand:" "Everybody's waiting / For the moment to arrive / I will clear my vision / See the water on the rise / The wave is beginning / Will we make it out alive? / Feet are stuck in quicksand / And we're running out of time" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Cody Simpson confirmed in a 2017 interview with iHeartRadio that the song is inspired by sea level rise and ocean conservation (iHeartRadio).

works.notes: "The Great Dying" is one of several tracks on the album "Death Atlas" that includes a narration about climate change, and it is included in the database for explicit references to climate change, biodiversity loss, rising sea levels, and melting ice. The narration on this track includes the following: "Environmental scientists and engineers all describe the current era as planet Earth's sixth mass extinction. Its cause - humans. Approximately half of all now living plant and animal species in the world's densely biodiverse regions are risking extinction due to global warming and climate change. The rate the world's sea level is rising suggests that it may lead to a rapid change which would create momentous problems for citizens that live in coastal regions. This has led scientists to describe these days as the Anthropocene - the new geological era constructed by humans. The recent unparalleled temperatures in the Arctic as well as the data showing abnormal rises in upper atmospheric methane levels converge to give the impression that the near future of the entire human race is at stake" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Greenhouse" by Evildead is included in the database for explicit references to global warming and the greenhouse effect. The song references a number of environmental issues, notably various forms of pollution and its effects on humans, including cancer, but the lyrics do include this direct reference to the greenhouse effect: "Temperature rises every day / Try to stop it there's no way / Skin cancer no answer / Dissipate the oxygen / Greenhouse keeps the heat in..." (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Friday's On" by Ziggy Marley is included in the database for explicit references to climate change as well as lyrical and video references to the youth climate movement's school walkout protests in 2019 known as "Fridays For Future." The song's lyrics focus on how the world's youth are protesting in the streets demanding action to address climate change and gun violence: "To all the youths dem / Standing up to gun violence / Standing up to man made climate change / Power to the children / Out of school / Into the streets / Friday’s on / The vibe is real" (Genius Lyrics). The song's title and video clearly refer to the Fridays For Future movement (also known as School Strike for Climate) that inspired millions of students around the world to walk out of school on several Fridays in 2019 to protest inaction on climate change (Wikipedia).

works.work_title: The Effects of Climate Change on Densely Populated Areas
works.notes: "The Effects of Climate Change on Densely Populated Areas" by People Under the Stairs is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change in the song title and for extensive discussion of heat waves in Los Angeles exacerbated by climate change within the lyrics. The song points out many examples of how intense summer heat, which is getting more intense over time, affects people: "As the sun begins to set it's hotter, no-one can chill / Everybody's windows open there's not a moment of silence / Alcohol heatin' frustration that's increasing domestic violence / 9-1-1 is overwhelmed, homie, guess you on your own / The hills are still on fire, I recommend you stay at home" (Genius Lyrics). The song samples "(Love is Like A) Heat Wave" by Martha & The Vandellas.

works.notes: Sepultura's "Guardians of Earth" is included in the database for climate-specific context surrounding the song, including a music video depicting indigenous people defending the Amazon Rainforest in collaboration with the climate and indigenous rights organization Amazon Front Lines (YouTube). The lyrics do not mention climate change, but they draw a clear connection between the fate of humanity and the fate of the earth: "Our earth / Our salvation / Slips through / Our hands are tied / We've sold our souls / There's no place to hide / Why? We closed our eyes / There's no second chance / Self-destruction / By speaking the truth / We stay alive" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: Bill Madden's "Unfair" makes a lyrical plea for allowing the innocence and optimism of young people to shine (without mention of climate change), but it is included in the database for how the music video connects generational change to the battle over fossil fuels, carbon emissions, and technological development. The video tells the story of a boy who builds the world's "first petroleum free vehicle" from plans that were supposed to be destroyed by an organization called the "Petroleum Protection Agency," illustrating a fictional but relevant example of the fossil fuel industry fighting against the adoption of new technologies designed to lower carbon emissions and prevent climate change (YouTube).

works.notes: "How Dare You" is a death metal song recorded by Suaka drummer John Meredith using a portion of climate activist Greta Thunberg's speech at the United Nations in 2019 as the vocal track. It is included in the database because the speech is an explicit call to action to address climate change. Snippets of the speech included in the song: "My message is that we'll be watching you. This is all wrong. I shouldn't be up here. I should be back in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you all come to us young people for hope. How dare you! You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words. And yet I'm one of the lucky ones. People are suffering. People are dying. Entire ecosystems are collapsing. We are in the beginning of a mass extinction, and all you can talk about is money and fairy tales of eternal economic growth. How dare you! For more than 30 years, the science has been crystal clear. How dare you continue to look away and come here saying that you're doing enough, when the politics and solutions needed are still nowhere in sight. You say you hear us and that you understand the urgency. But no matter how sad and angry I am, I do not want to believe that. Because if you really understood the situation and still kept on failing to act, then you would be evil. And that I refuse to believe" (NPR).

works.media_link_title: Rolling Stone - How Greta Thunberg got a Metal Makeover

works.notes: "Apocalypse Today" by The Casualties is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change within a broader criticism of mankind's destruction of the environment. In the last two lines before the chorus, vocalist Jorge Herrera screams "Endangered species dying one by one / Complete global warming, pollution blocks the sun" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "hydrogen," the first track on Sirintip's album "carbon," is included in the database for context provided in album notes that confirms a lyrical and titular connection to climate change through renewable energy. According to notes provided on Bandcamp for this track, "Hydrogen is the most common element in the universe. Through science and innovation, green hydrogen could be a great source of renewable energy in the future. The lyrics are written from the perspective of being hydrogen" (Bandcamp). This reference to renewable energy, specifically nuclear fusion, taken in the context of the album's connection to climate change, constitutes a reference to climate change.

works.notes: "The Globe" by Big Audio Dynamite II is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. The song, which also makes a reference to the environmental issue of acid rain, mentions global warming by name: "Awaking up the global warming way / Napalm cornflakes for my Special K" (Genius Lyrics). One of the verses portrays the desire to go out and party before facing death, referring to rising temperatures, which may be an additional reference: "Get up and clean your teeth and have a shave / It's 1 am, let's go out to a rave / One more in before we hit that grave / It's hotter than a microwave, wave" (Genius Lyrics). The lyrics specifically about global warming do not appear in the radio edit of this song.

works.work_title: The Wolf is at the Door
works.notes: "The Wolf is at the Door," a song written and performed by Reply All host Alex Goldman with inspiration from climate journalist Emily Atkin, is included in the database for several explicit references to climate change. According to Reply All podcast episode #170, "A Song of Impotent Rage," Alex Goldman wrote the song to express feelings of anger and helplessness in the face of climate change. Lyric snippets: "Sea levels rising... / In all honesty, I am incredibly stressed out about systemic climate change, and I don't know what the solution is... / Your climate plan isn't good enough / You can go to hell" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Resistance" by Queensrÿche is included in the database for context surrounding the song provided by lead singer Geoff Tate. In an interview with KMUW Wichita in 2021, Tate directly ties the meaning of the song to climate change: "“Resistance” is about the climate change debate and the results of climate change, what it’s been doing to the civilized world" (kmuw.org). The song's lyrics, given this context, take on a more specific meaning: "Burning coal / Got to keep the company warm as / The rain keeps killing the trees / Cut 'em down quick / Pay the man his wage, he's making paper / To fuel the "Information Age" / Out in the midwest / Hear the roar of the plough / Turning grassland into sand / Got to feed the people more every day / But the wind keeps blowing the land away" (Genius Lyrics). This verse identifies three major causes of climate change, namely the burning of fossil fuels such as coal, deforestation, and industrial agriculture. The song emphasizes acts of resistance against this environmental destruction: "Protests in New York / Listen to the call of the wild / Brother, sisters carrying signs/ Breathe deep before it's too late" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Planet B" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song opens the album "Infest the Rats' Nest," a concept album telling the story of a group of humans leaving earth to escape environmental disasters and colonize other planets (Wikipedia, album booklet). The song title, and the repeated lyric "There is no Planet B," echoes a slogan long used in discourse on the environment and climate change (Genius Lyrics, audio track, Google). In addition, the lyrics reference fossil fuel usage ("Open your eyes and light the fluid / Get into it, petrol siphon"), agricultural failure from drought ("Low on meals, browning fields ... / Rusting tractors"), and descriptions of earth's climate permanently changing ("Patient seasons / Blacked out for ages ... / Snowflakes blanket / Old deserts") (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: Esperanza Spalding's "Endangered Species" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song describes the relationship between humans and mother earth, characterizing mother earth as endangered by humans but ultimately grounded by her, falling from the heights of technological progress. The lyrics include several references to fossil fuels ("Mighty jet planes fly," "No one hears it through the din as engines burn," "Swarms with cars and poison," "Blowing up the mountains foul oil fountains"), and describes a scenario in which humans will suffer the consequences of burning fossil fuels: "What burns up must come down / Human nature / Scrambling late to curb hard consequences" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.work_title: Big Boy Diamonds feat. Kodak Black
works.notes: "Big Boy Diamonds" by Gucci Mane is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. Gucci Mane repeatedly uses the phrase "changin' the climate" throughout the song, including a line in the final verse that explicitly mentions global warming: "I caught a rash from countin' the money / I'm changin' the climate like global warming (Bling) / She seen the charm and said I'm charming / The watch on my arm, it come with an army" (Genius Lyrics). This reference creates a double meaning for the phrase "changin' the climate," which adds context to a line in the chorus about ice (diamonds): "Big boy diamonds / Ice on me changin' the climate" (Genius Lyrics). It is possible that "ice," a slang word for diamond jewelry, alludes to the idea of a temperature change, given the context of the global warming reference.

works.notes: "Revolution" by Heavy Water is included in the database for confirmation by the songwriters that the song is about climate change. The lyrics include a call to a revolution in response to withheld information: "Take us for fools, set the rules, I just can't understand / So many secrets they won't tell us, yeah we're in demand / Yeah, they don't want you to know ... This is a revolution / I see no other solution / This is a revolution / This is a world in confusion" (Genius Lyrics). According to the description of the song posted on the music video by the PlanetSaxon channel, which hosts music from Heavy Water and other projects associated with singer and guitarist Biff Byford, "We wrote this about global warming... not being told the truth about the impact over the years" (YouTube).

works.notes: "hostage" by Sirintip is included in the database for track notes tying the environmental themes in the lyrics directly to climate change. The song personifies mother earth in a state of damage and suffering, criticizing the human race for their role in environmental destruction: "you strapped your foot / around my neck / and wonder why i’ve changed / i’m bound by the air / the promises / that you suffocate" (Bandcamp). The changes referred to in this verse are climate change, as described in the track notes: "This is one of the few songs on the album where the climate concern is clearly in the lyrics where mother earth is asking us to treat her better and letting her go from the grip that we have on her" (Bandcamp).

works.notes: "My Name is Dark" by Grimes is included in the database for lyrics that, according the artist's verified annotations on Genius Lyrics, represent a prayer to futuristic, technological gods including the Goddess of climate change. Lyrics snippet: "And the angel of death, she said to God / 'Un-fuck the world, un-fuck the world / You stupid girl, you stupid girl'" (Genius Lyrics). According to Grimes' verified Genius Lyrics annotation for these 3 lines: "A big theme on my album is this idea of new Gods, modern, post-technological Gods. Miss Anthropocene is for the goddess of climate change or whatever. All the songs are kind of talking to the new Gods. They’re all about what happens, what’s a 21st century prayer to a techno God. What does that sound like? That’s kind of like the thesis. That was kind of like summing up the song, pulling the song back to the album thesis" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Angélique Kidjo's "Mother Nature" is included in the database for context surrounding the song that specifically ties it to climate change, as well as lyrics that refer to sea level rise and urge collaboration to address the crisis. "Mother Nature" is the title track on Kidjo's 2021 album. On the Apple Music album description, Kidjo explicitly ties the album as a whole to climate change: “When I became pregnant, it was obvious to ask myself the question: What kind of world are we going to leave to our children and beyond?” she tells Apple Music. “And it became more and more relevant as I started seeing the proof of climate change—let me start writing a love letter to Mother Earth, Mother Nature" (Apple Music). This thematic tie to climate change highlights a lyrical reference to rising sea levels and coastal damage: "Don't ever let 'em hurt you in any way / Oh never let them steal and take the best of you / Keep building cities from the ground / We're rising with the waves" (Genius Lyrics). Furthermore, her description of suddenly noticing proof of climate changes gives significance to Mother Nature's "warning" and a "time bomb" in the lyrics, possibly representing the limited amount of time left to address climate change: "Mother Nature has a way of warning us / A time bomb set on a lost countdown / Do you hear it? Will you stop it? / Won't you listen?" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Girls" by Shunaji is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change through the idea of ice melting. The song, which according to the artist "is an intimate conversation with all my sisters worldwide, a message about the society we live in and its impact on young girls and women," briefly creates a juxtaposition between paradise and reality in the first verse that mentions a lack of ice melting in an ideal world: "Marquees, people living wealthy / Paradise and the ice is never melting / And the glass is never empty / Meanwhile, on the other side / Black boys profiled, police gone wild / Racially hostile is the world / Never chill no chill for a girl" (bandcamp). The idea that in an ideal world where "the glass is never empty" (and there is no racism), that "ice is never melting," strongly implies that this consequence of global warming as an example of something wrong with the real world.

works.notes: "Chemtrails" by Anvil is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming and its relationship to carbon dioxide emissions. The song is mainly about the debunked Chemtrails conspiracy theory, but the fourth verse mentions global warming: "Call it conspiracy, deny the real fact / Vanishing vapor trail, you know it's a murderous act / They say there's global warming, carbon dioxide to blame / A raping of the money, stupidity and shame" (Genius Lyrics). The song's stance on global warming is unclear, as is the connection to the Chemtrails conspiracy, but one possible explanation for the reference is the erroneous belief that condensation trails left by aircraft constitute attempts at chemical geoengineering to reverse the effects of global warming or otherwise manipulate the weather (Wikipedia). While the song is mainly supporting an erroneous, conspiratorial belief, the lyrics notably tie the phenomenon of global warming to carbon dioxide emissions, a relationship that is well grounded in scientific evidence (climate.gov).

works.notes: B**** Suck Dick (B.S.D.) by Tyler, the Creator is included in the database for a brief, humorous reference to global warming during the verse performed by Jasper Dolphin, a fellow member of Hip Hop collective Odd Future (Genius Lyrics, Wikipedia). Jasper contrasts global warming to the Ice Age, using a common slang meaning of "ice" to refer to diamonds on his wristwatch being large enough to compare to the ice at the top of Mount Everest: "Mount Everest ain't f***ing with my f***ing wrist / F*** global warming, this the Ice Age, b****!" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Kreator's "When The Sun Burns Red" is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming and significant lyrical themes involving various aspects of climate change, including forest fires, heat waves, and numerous examples of severe weather. The song notably points to human activity as the cause of this destruction: "Savage heat is searing / Global warming has begun / Mother Earth is reeling / No protection from the sun / Forest fires are raging / While the rivers turn to ice / Foolish man creating / Mother Nature's cruel demise / Hailstorms, tornadoes / Cold spells, untimely frosts / Heat waves and blizzards / Global death's the cost / Faces the end of time / As we plunge headlong towards the day / Can't deny the signs / When the sun burns red / The earth will turn / From blue to gray " (Genius lyrics).

works.notes: Flobots' "Defend Atlantis" is included in the database for numerous references to climate change. The song describes a group of island people adapting to sea level rise by adopting new ideas about collaboration and leaving old structures (both physical and conceptual) behind. The sea level rise is clearly the result of climate change in the context of the song based on references to melting ice caps and to global warming specifically. Lyric snippet: "That which creates life has power to take it right back / Fucking with the ice caps / We've gotta push the tide back / We can survive collapse / If we don't get sidetracked ... We float on tsunami to global warming / We need structures to control what's coming / Corporate monopolies obsolete / That philosophy leaves us lost at sea / But from Marwar to Cochabamba / We are the warriors that won't get conquered / Cause rising tides drown all villages / Divided fighters succumb to pillage" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "The Truth Comes Out" by Corb Lund is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change through a description of specific changes in the climate and its effects on wildlife distribution. Lyric snippet: "The weather's been funny thirty years or so / The winters got warm, and not as much snow / Hear the big cats comin' cuz there's nowhere left to go" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). The song also refers to other environmental themes including overhunting of Buffalo by westerners and the wisdom of indigenous knowledge: "Well half-heard voices from the ghosts, from the graves / The grandfathers tell us at the mouths of the caves / Only old chiefs older than Jesus can save us now, if we're lucky / White man light a big fire, stay cold / The red man's warmer, but the old man's old / The antelope seeks the buffalo in the night / The antelope mourns the buffalo in the night" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "Down" by Lupe Fiasco is included included for a brief but clear reference to climate change in the second verse: "Throw us in the water, execution / We really thought we wasn't gonna do nothin' / But the sharks and the dolphins gonna do somethin' / Walked up out that water, evolution / Ayy, ayy, revolution / Pass the plate, you should make a contribution / If you ain't got it then you gotta go and get it / Climate change, chain flooded, call it sleepin' with the fishes / Tired of all these bitches, in my net it's just fishes" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). This song, as part of the concept inspiring the album, tells the story of slaves thrown off of ships into the ocean who make friends with ocean wildlife and become powerful, instead of the expected outcome of death (Wikipedia). In this context, climate change is listed as a synonym of execution, alongside "sleeping with the fishes" and "chain flooded."

works.notes: "Sea Gets Hotter" by Durand Jones & The Indications is included in the database for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change. The title of the song and the chorus refer to the warming of the oceans, which is a clear consequence of global warming. Furthermore, the song's second verse makes additional references to changes in weather: "Grayin' with the gatherin' storm and the smoke hangs on the breeze / I know that I got you and you know that you got me" (Genius Lyrics). While indirect, these allusions to weather, taken together, clearly call to mind global warming and two direct consequences of it: increased intensity of storms and wildfire smoke. The chorus emphasizes the gravity of climate change and the desire to run away from it with a loved one, mentioning "the world's weight upon us:" "Said the sea gets hotter / And the drums beat louder / And world seems colder / Singing that same old tune / And the times get harder / World's weight upon us / But it don't mean nothin' / Cause we're leavin' soon" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Supercell" by King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard is included in the database for implicit lyrical references to climate change that establish a link between fossil fuels and extreme weather. The lyrics describe enormous deadly tornadoes and the destruction and death they cause, which is linked in multiple songs and the narrative arc of the album to the worship of the "Motor Spirit," a deity associated with fossil fuels and the internal combustion engine. "Supercell" connects the power of the destructive tornadoes directly to the wrath of the Motor Spirit: "24 dead in my state/ Motor spirit subjugate / Creator, a burning mouth / Carnage North, East, West, and South / EF5, force of nature / Demolition, meet your maker / Throwing cities like leaves / Our mortal surface is wiped clean" (Genius lyrics). "EF5" is a tornado classification, and the statistic "24 dead in my state" may refer to deaths in the state of Mississippi during early 2023 due to tornadoes (NOAA). It is important to note that the links between climate change and tornado intensity and frequency are not firmly established (NOAA fact sheet). Despite this uncertainty, the subtext of climate change as an unnamed link between the Motor Spirit and environmental destruction is present throughout lyrics in this song and the entire album concept.

works.notes: "One Candle", a collaboration between film composer J. Ralph and pop singer Sia, is included in the database for its inclusion in the documentary "Racing Extinction," which covers biodiversity loss for reasons including climate change. The song's lyrics include an environmental call to action on behalf of species that existed before humans: "I’m breathing, give thanks for they have given / Listen to all the songs I’m singing / We can do something or do nothing / So come now, strike the match, lets do this / Together we can / Take my hand, take my hand / (Now I won’t stand around the dark) / Together we can light our candles and stand for those who came before man / (Now I won’t stand around the dark)" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Mitski's "Nobody" is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. The themes of the song include loneliness and alienation, and in the first verse, Mitski refers to the uninhabitable conditions of the planet Venus caused by the greenhouse effect in its atmosphere: "My God, I'm so lonely, so I open the window / To hear sounds of people, to hear sounds of people / Venus, planet of love, was destroyed by global warming / Did its people want too much too? Did its people want too much?" (Genius Lyrics). Mitski poses the question of whether fictional former inhabitants of the planet Venus wanted "too much too," which may in part be a comparison to how human consumption is contributing to climate change on earth.

works.notes: Chali 2na's "Show Me" covers many topics, including politics, war, slavery, and police brutality, and it is included in the database for several references to global warming and the burning of fossil fuels. The chorus of the song uses the phrase "I need someone to show me" following a statement that the subject is skeptical or critical of, and the second example of this includes a reaction to climate denial: "They telling me global warming's a fantasy but (I need someone to show me)" (Genius Lyrics). Later in the song, Chali 2na ties global warming to oil production and foreign policy: "Foreign soil occupation for oil confiscation / Politicians make the climate hot as satan" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Fredrika Stahl's song "Tomorrow," written for the 2015 French documentary of the same name, is included in the database for implicit lyrical references to climate change and the subject material of the film it was written for. The lyrics refer to a future environmental crisis that can be resolved based on actions taken today, with one direct reference to "facing a storm" (Genius lyrics). Lyric snippets: "It's always so hard to see / How things could turn out differently / But we're in a mess now / I feel it we're facing a wall / Fight it out wipe out the wrong / Fight for us we must go on / The whole world is on hold now / I feel it we're facing a storm / See the final show now / Face the final blow now / Start looking around you will get it all the omens all the signs / Believe we can change for the better make some good things down the line / For tomorrow we'll reap what we sow today tomorrow will be if we change" (Genius lyrics). While the indirect lyrics could easily be applied to climate change, the lyric video for the song published by Stahl's label (Cristal Records) is more explicit in its imagery, depicting many scenes of low-carbon technologies (solar panels and wind farms) and video footage of fossil fuel extraction and pollution from power plants (youtube). Finally, the documentary explicitly covers energy solutions to climate change and was played at COP 21, tying the song definitively to climate change through this additional context (Wikipedia).

works.notes: Cradle of Filth's "Suffer Our Dominion" is included for an explicit reference and many implicit references to climate change throughout a dark song outlining the devastating effects of mankind on the environment and the expected retribution from Mother Nature. English actor Doug Bradley provides narration for the introduction of the song that specifically mentions biodiversity loss due to climate change: "The ability to sustain life on earth is shrinking in perfect unison with rising population. Soon, half of all species will be lost to climate change and ecological collapse due to human activity. Thus we either reduce our race voluntarily or nature will do it for us. And she will be fucking brutal" (Genius Lyrics). The remainder of the song follows this theme of mutual destruction, naming several causes and effects of climate change, including "naive consumption," "acidifying seas," "mass extinction," and "Jungles culled, sold on or cindered" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Converge" by King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard is included in the database for continuing the strong implicit reference to climate change in the lyrics of the album "Petrodragonic Apocalypse." The song describes the formation of superstorms ravaging the earth as enormous tornadoes merge together, continuing the narrative of destruction after the songs "Motor Spirit" and "Supercell." Lyrics snippet: "A tempest of great force and might / A storm of such unparalleled fright / The winds do howl, the rains do pour / The lightning strike, the thundеr roar / The elemеnts rage in wild excess / A spectacle of cruel finesse / Houses, cities, torn asunder / The havoc wreaked, a sight to wonder / May the lord have mercy on us all / Pray the storm which risen, thus shall fall" (Genius lyrics). The lyrics connect this destruction to the worship of the Motor Spirit, continuing the album's allusion to climate change: "I am removed, I am a cloud / In peering down, I am endowed / Motor spirit, that brought me here / Fly to the moon, I have no fear / The twisters worm as tyres burn / The screeching rims, Gale force winds / The judgement day, murder tycoon / Ground control from the bird's eye view" (Genius lyrics). The line "Motor spirit, that brought be here" could literally refer to the fossil fuel that powered a rocket to space to escape the deadly storms, or it could figuratively establish the causality between worshipping the Motor Spirit and the storms, and idea firmly developed in the previous two tracks.

works.notes: "Motor Spirit" by King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard is included in the database for a deeply developed implicit lyrical reference to climate change. The first track on the album "Petrodragonic Apocalypse," the song sets up the world in which the album's story takes place, a barren, fiery desert full of highways in which mankind consumes fossil fuels and worships a deity called the "Motor Spirit." The practice of worshipping the Motor Spirit and consuming fossil fuels has all sorts of ill effects on humanity, from death and illness ("Highway death by Motor Spirit," "Bloody stool," "Fire pious side effects") to weather disasters: "Dire fate shall plague our land / Hurricanes shall sweepeth sand / The winds doth howl and moaneth / Homes and lives overthrowneth" (Genius lyrics). The lyrics clearly place the blame on humanity for worshipping the Motor Spirit and bringing about these harms, with the narrator begging for forgiveness: "Engine Gaia, piston wheeze / The messiah on their knees / Beg the wind, beg the tree / Beg the bug for mercy / Motor spirit, dragon race / Burning cars, outer space / Petrol king, abdicate / Human-kind, exonerate" (Genius lyrics). The relationship between the consumption and worship of fossil fuels and a destructive change in weather patterns creates an unnamed but powerful allusion to climate change that continues to be developed in other songs on the album, including "Supercell." The relationship between the album as a whole and climate change was noted by music critics including NPR music contributor Matthew Perpetua in his review of "Petrodragonic Apocalypse" (npr.org).

works.notes: Mo'Ju's "Change Has To Come," an invigorating and funky call to action, is included in the database for strong implicit references to climate change in both the lyrics and the song's music video. The lyrics do not mention global warming or climate change by name, but they highlight warning signs of a future storm in the context of calling for action: "Can’t you hear the bell signal the warning? / Here comes the storm / Best we be gone" (Lyrics in YouTube Description). Furthermore, the lyrics frequently create a motif of motion upwards, through the words "rising" and "elevate" in the chorus, while in parallel the music video depicts Mo'Ju and their band performing as water rises slowly rises to their heads, creating a clear visual reference to flooding or sea level rise. The song was nominated for the 2023 Environmental Music Prize, and on the song's entry page, Mo'Ju links the music video specifically to Australian bush fires and flooding, both of which are exacerbated by climate change: "When I first started writing this song we were experiencing bushfires all over the country. By the time I made the video in 2022, we were experiencing unprecedented flooding around the country. I wanted to make something simple that evoked both fire and flood and spoke to the urgency of the situation. So you will see tonally the colour palette is of burnt orange and reds, but as the video progresses there is water rising around us, which eventually reaches our necks. There is also a sun setting behind us, a metaphor for time running out and the sun setting on our life as we know it, if we continue to let the waters rise" (Environmental Music Prize).

works.notes: Grimes and i_o's song "Violence" is included in the database for the context of Grimes' description of the album's themes related to climate change and elements of the music video. The lyrics depict a lover singing to a partner about how they both allow and depend on violence inflicted on the subject: "I'm, like, begging for it, baby / Makes you wanna party, wanna wake up / Baby, it's violence, violence / Baby, it's violence / But you can't see what I see / You can't see what I see / 'Cause you, ha, ha, you feed off hurting me / Off hurting me, yeah, ha-ha" (Genius lyrics). Alone, the lyrics do not make a reference to climate change, but when taken in the context of Grimes' description of the album's themes, it is easy to envision song's subject as the earth. Grimes posted a description of the album in 2019 on her Instagram: "It’s called Miss_Anthropocene. It’s a concept album about the anthropomorphic Goddess of climate Change: A psychedelic, space-dwelling demon/ beauty-Queen who relishes the end of the world. She’s composed of Ivory and Oil. Each song will be a different embodiment of human extinction as depicted through a Pop star Demonology" (NME). The music video for "Violence" ends with an image of a fairy figure plunging a sword through a bleeding earth, similar to the image used in some versions of the album's cover art, enforcing the idea that the Goddess of climate change is the perpetrator of the violence discussed in the song (YouTube).

works.notes: "Forever Begins" by Common is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming amidst other calamities faced by humanity, in wide-ranging and varied song that explores civil rights, humanity, and spirituality. In the song's outro, narrated by basketball player Lonnie "Pops" Lynn, a list of hardships is recited: "Tsunamis, hurricanes following the trails of the African slave ships / War, war, and more war / Floods, Columbine, global warming, earthquakes / Another somebody done me wrong, son" (Genius Lyrics). The song does end on a hopeful note, though, with Pops saying the following: "Sift the ingredients / Of acknowledgment, apology, amendment, atonement / We gon' work with the four A's here / Forever, Pops / Common good is forever / God's memory is forever" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "My Fancy Free Future Love" by Common is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. The song is a love song, and the global warming reference occurs in an extended metaphor about weather and the rough times in relationships: "let's go on / We we-weather-weather the storm / Love comes through and we get it on / Been through the PM just to see the dawn / They say it never rains in Californ' / That done changed 'cause of global warming / Depends on what you use for a lens / I was told God used rain to cleanse" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Shame, Shame, Shame" by Lake Street Dive is included in the database for being used as the introduction music for the Environmental Defense Fund's climate change careers podcast "Degrees." The show is described as "your podcast community for green job mentors, insight into new and growing careers, advice to calm your climate anxiety, and actionable conversations to make a meaningful impact in the world" (edf.org). In an interview on "Degrees" season 3 episode 1, Lake Street Dive lead singer Rachael Price discusses the meaning of the song. While lyricist Bridget Kearney wrote the song with inspiration from former United States President Donald Trump, the song was selected by podcast host Yesh Pavlik Slenk because of the lyrics "Change is comin', oh yeah" (Spotify).

works.notes: Gojira's "Global Warming" is included in the database for its titular reference to global warming. The song depicts the regretful reflections of a being on the destruction of their home planet. Lyric snippet: "And we are just taking everything for granted / I don't think we should do this now / And when I see the smoke around / I feel like I'm not from humankind down there / I feel like glaciers are my eyes / And mountains are my head, my heart is ocean / And I feel all alone" (Genius lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "When the Bulbs Burn Out," a song that depicts the collapse of human civilization due to environmental destruction, is included in the database for the use of an audio recording of actor and climate activist Leonardo DiCaprio speaking at the United Nations climate summit in 2014. The song's introduction includes the following parts of the speech: "Every week we're seeing new and undeniable climate events. Evidence that accelerated climate change is here right now... Droughts are intensifying. Our oceans are acidifying. Methane levels rising up in the ocean floor... We are seeing extreme weather events. The west Antarctic ice shifts melting at unprecedented rate. Decades ahead of scientific projections... None of this is rhetoric, and none of it is hysteria. It is fact. And solving this is not a question of politics. It is a question of our own survival" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Collapse (Post-Amerika)" by Rise Against is included in the database for explicit references to both droughts and warming in the opening verse: "When our rivers run dry and our crops cease to grow / When our summers grow longer and winters won't snow" (Genius Lyrics). This reference accompanies many other environmental themes. The chorus touches on ignorance of climate change and other environmental issues, describing the human race as "too proud to admit our mistakes:" "That's how we'll know / This is not a test, we'll know / This is cardiac arrest / Of a world too proud to admit our mistakes / We're crashing into the ground as we all fall from grace" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Rising Seas" by Midnight Oil is included in the database for numerous explicit references to climate change. The song focuses on climate change consequences (rising sea levels, rising temperatures) in the context of economics and capitalism (disadvantaging future generations for profits in the present, extracting resources, and disruptions in markets). Lyric snippet: "Every child put down your toys / And come inside to sleep / We have to look you in the eye and say we sold you cheap / Let's confess we did not act / With serious urgency / So open up the floodgates / To the rising seas / Temperature rising / Climate denying / Fever is gripping / Nobody's listening / Lustre is fading / Because nobody's trading / Wall Street is jumping / Still, the music keeps pumping" (Genius Lyrics). Furthermore, the song's music video includes footage of glaciers melting, storm damage, power plant emissions, and other imagery connected to climate change, as well as a call to action at the end, criticizing 2050 climate goals as "too far away" and linking to climate advocacy organizations such as Greenpeace (YouTube).

works.notes: "A Beautiful Lie" is included in the database for climate change context surrounding the song, such as a glacier on the artwork for the single, a music video filmed in the arctic that explicitly draws attention to polar ice melting, and associations with environmental groups including National Resources Defense Council (Wikipedia). In a revised version of the music video posted on YouTube in 2010, an Inuit Hunter named Ulrik Sanimuniaaq describes how arctic ice is now too thin to use traditional hunting methods, the band performs on top of glaciers, and data is shown at the end explaining significant recent ice sheet losses (YouTube). The lyrics are vague and do not reference climate change directly, but the chorus lyrics could conceivably be interpreted to represent climate denial (not confirmed): "It's a beautiful lie / It's a perfect denial / Such a beautiful lie to believe in / So beautiful, beautiful it makes me" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "99 In October" by The RTs is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to global warming. The song uses two references to Farenheit temperatures at particular times of year, both of them intended to metaphorically indicate warmth in the context of a relationship. "99 in October" and "88 in December" are both quite hot relative to expectations for Fall and Winter months for states in the US, even the most southern states. For example, Florida, known for its warm, beach-friendly weather year-round, would be considered unusually hot at 99 degrees Farhenheit in October (tripsavvy.com). In the context of the song's lyrical themes, the unusually high temperatures in the Fall and Winter are signifying that Summer, representing the warmth of a romance, is not over yet, at least according to the hopes of the song's narrator: "99 in October / This summer's far from over / Why don't you even come over? / Before too long we'll be older / And it'll be colder / We'll be looking back over our shoulder/ 88 in December / Our love's now a glowing ember" (Spotify).

works.notes: Passenger's "A Kindly Reminder" is included in the database for political commentary about climate change. The song, clearly directed at the recently inaugurated 45th United States President Donald Trump, criticizes his skepticism and denial of climate change: "And I heard you say climate change isn't real / But that's not how the world's leading scientists feel / So go bury your head in the sand if you will / But the waters are rising around Capitol Hill" (Genius Lyrics). Trump's statements on climate change over the years have varied greatly in meaning but have often referred to it as a hoax, according to a Washington Post article published only months before Trump's inauguration and the release of this song (Washington Post).

works.notes: According to co-songwriter Myles Kennedy in an interview for MusicRadar, "It's about the global warming denying phenomenon that is taking place" (MusicRadar). "The Writing On The Wall" repeatedly casts blame for "denying the greatest sin" and "the rate of change," which both refer directly to climate change, given the context of the interview. Lyric snippets: "Refusing every warning / Deny the rate of change / The ignorance is swarming / What a shame / Then you know that you're to blame / You're to blame / And the writing's on the wall / That the end will begin / Still, you do nothing at all / Throwing lies to the wind / And the writing's on the wall / So I say it again / Still, you do nothing at all / And keep denying the greatest sin" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "I Like How It Feels" by Enrique Iglesias featuring Pitbull is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming during Pitbull's rapped verse. Pitbull raps the lines "Baby, just close your eyes / And imagine any part in the world / I've been there (I've been there) / I'm like global warming / Anything I just start to heat the things up / But I've been here (Haha)" (Genius Lyrics). Here, Pitbull refers literally to the heat from global warming in a humorous, self-aggrandizing fashion.

works.notes: "Global Warming" by Sasha Alex Sloan is included in the database for an explicit reference in the title of the song and strong implicit references to global warming in the lyrics. Sloan laments bad air quality changing the color of the sky and expresses concern for the earth in the opening verse: "Most days / The sky ain't as blue as it's supposed to be (Supposed to be) / And most days / I'm scared for the planet underneath my feet (Underneath my feet)" (Genius Lyrics). In a much more specific reference to global warming, Sloan sings "We're burnin' up like a cigarette / Everyone we love's gonna end up dead" several times throughout the song, dramatically making a clear reference to either global warming itself or to wildfires exacerbated by climate change (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "From the Greenhouse" by Crack the Sky is included in the database for an explicit reference to the greenhouse effect, a mechanism that greatly influences climate change (NASA). Songwriter John Palumbo originally wrote the album's songs for a solo project in 1988 that reflected "his anxiety over the global warming phenomenon" according to a newspaper article published by J.S. Considine in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch on April 27th, 1990 (newspapers.com). The album contains numerous references to environmental themes, with song titles such as "Under Red Skies" and "The Frozen Rain," and the album art depicts a crowd of faces colored in infra-red hues turned upwards to a murky sky (Wikipedia). Lyric snippet: "After all we've been through / Doesn't it seem a little funny to you / We should all shine from the violet blue / And now we're calling you / From the greenhouse / All of the warriors have gone away / I sit and watch the sky, waiting for the rain" (Genius Lyrics, Discogs).

works.notes: "Global Warming" by The Acacia Strain is included in the database for its title and clear references to the 2006 climate change documentary "An Inconvenient Truth" in the lyrics. The song, which conveys an intent to destroy humanity and the environment, switches the meaning of the documentary title with the phrase "This is a very convenient truth," used twice (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Atlantic" by The Weather Station is included in the database for context surrounding the album and for strong implicit lyrical references to climate change. In an interview with Pitchfork Media in 2021, frontwoman Tamara Lindeman indicates climate change as a major inspiration for the album's themes. "I don’t think you can come into contact with the reality of what 2 degrees of warming means and not become radical," Lindeman says in the interview, and the article goes on to explain that "as she wrote the songs for Ignorance, sifting through her own feelings, she set out to create a space to guide listeners out of the nihilism that thoughts of climate destruction can bring" (Pitchfork Media). In this context, the lyrics in "Atlantic" clearly refer to climate change as a dark thought that is difficult to face head-on: "Thinking I should get all this dying off of my mind / I should really know better than to read the headlines / Does it matter if I see it? / No really, can I not just cover my eyes?" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "The Unerasable Past" by Cattle Decapitation is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change and for discussion of the issue of climate migration. This track mostly consists of a spoken narration about climate change, and it is placed before the final song on the regular release of the album "Death Atlas" (Wikipedia). Jon Fishman, the drummer of the jam band Phish, performed the narration, which includes the following: "The recent unparalleled temperatures in the arctic, as well as the data showing abnormal rises in upper atmosphere methane levels, converge to give the impression that the near future of the entire human race is at stake. In 2018 the World Bank Group reported that many countries will need to prepare for over 100-million displaced people, as well as the displacement of millions of international refugees due to the ill effects of climate change. It has become clear that an enormous operation and policy program to revolutionize agriculture and repair the Earth's ecosystems is immediately needed" (Wikipedia, Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Funcoland vs. the Southern Electorate" by Bomb The Music Industry! is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming. According to the song description on Quote Unquote Records' website, "We were at our first Bomb the Music Industry! practice and John's amp wouldn't work so he blew on it. We asked him what the hell he was doing and he said he didn't know, he was trying to fix it like he would fix a Nintendo cartridge. He then suggested that it would be awesome if we could fix all of our problems like that, by blowing on them" (Quote Unquote Records). This song lists numerous problems, including global warming, that should wishfully be fixed by blowing on them: "Insurance, blow on it! / Debt, blow on it! / Global warming, blow on it! / Racist assholes, blow on it!" (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Nothing At All" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song's lyrics frequently return to the phrase "It's nothing at all" juxtaposed with warnings about environmental catastrophe, representing denial of the problem. When considered with a generational shift in attitudes on an environmental crisis ("But the children seem to be getting alarmed / Don't worry kids, it's nothing at all / When I hear about the doom and gloom / That's around the corner and coming soon / I take a sip of mother's ruin / And sit with my back to the wall"), as well a reference to the destructive power of Mother Nature in the form of winds ("And she blew all the leaves off my tree"), the song clearly references climate change denial (Genius Lyrics, audio track). The music video illustrates the denial with a man in a top hat and purple suit strutting about and claiming nothing is wrong while a trail of plastic pollution attaches itself to his suit and weighs him down, ultimately dragging him to the ground as he continues to sing "It's nothing at all" (Genius Lyrics, YouTube, audio track).

works.notes: "Love Me Down" by Jason Derulo is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming and an extended sexual innuendo using ideas of heat and natural disasters. The song opens with Derulo making advances on a woman at a club, comparing how hot the club atmosphere is to global warming and using disaster imagery: "Uh, I don't know if you heard 'bout that global warming and this club is first / Uh, we might all get hurt, your body is tsunami, mami, put in work (Good God) / You know I love the fur, you're blessed from behind, I'ma take you to church (Good God) / Uh, before we leave this Earth, shawty, can I get some?" (Genius Lyrics). Throughout the rest of the song, Derulo repeats his advances, repeating his desire to have fun in the moment before "the end of the world," which could be caused by global warming or a tsunami previously mentioned in the lyrics (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: Megadeth's "Dawn Patrol" is included in the database for an explicit reference to the greenhouse effect, a main driver of climate change. The lyrics depict a grim post-nuclear dystopia full of environmental hazards. Lyric snippets: "Awakened in the morning / To more air pollution warnings / Still we sleepwalk off to work... / With the greenhouse in effect / Our environment was wrecked" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: Muse's "Explorers" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. The song describes an overpopulated world on the verge of droughts and agricultural failures, with energy from nuclear fusion the only hope. The specific reference to nuclear fusion ("Fuse Helium-3 / Our last hope") implies a connection to the development of low-carbon energy sources currently under way to address climate change, which is largely caused by burning fossil fuels (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Lyrics snippet: "A world lush in bloom / With rivers running wild / They'll be rerouted South / With none left for you or for me / Don't give in / And hear the engines roar / And save our crops from drought / And when the black gold's in doubt / There's none left for you or for me / Fuse Helium-3 / Our last hope" (Genius Lyrics, audio track, album booklet).

works.notes: "Hey You" by Madonna is included in the database for context surrounding the song and for images used in the music video. Madonna wrote and recorded the song for the 2007 Live Earth concert, which was an event organized to raise awareness about climate change (Wikipedia). It was both recorded as a single for digital download and performed live at the concert. The music video for the studio version features various images, but the ones related to environmental themes include melting glaciers and automobiles (YouTube). The lyrics represent a call to action but do not specifically refer to climate change (Genius Lyrics).

works.notes: "Collateral Damage" by Shovels & Rope is included in the database for a strong implicit lyrical reference to greenhouse gases and climate change. In the first verse, "having babies" and "eating meat" are referred to as activities contributing to "collateral damage:" "Collateral damage, crowd control / Not sure who paid, not sure who stole / Somebody always pays when you get it on the cheap / So I stopped having babies and I stopped eating meat" (Genius Lyrics). In terms of greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to global warming, having one fewer child and adopting a vegetarian diet are both considered significant for individuals looking to reduce personal carbon footprint (Environmental Research Letters). Both of these specific lifestyle changes, considered together, clearly form an implicit reference to greenhouse gas emissions, indicating that the "collateral damage," at least in this verse, is climate change. Additionally, in this context, the lyric "Not sure who paid, not sure who stole" may refer to the difficulties in accounting for who is responsible for greenhouse gases and the lyric "Somebody always pays when you get it on the cheap" may indicate that global warming is the cost of the consumption of cheap fossil fuels, but these last two references are less clear-cut and thus unconfirmed.

works.notes: "I'm Dreaming" by Randy Newman, a dark and sarcastic song tackling issues of racism in American politics, is included in the song for an explicit reference to global warming. In the song's final verse, Newman includes a line about how the narrator's preferred white presidential candidate does not know much about global warming, making a clear reference to conservative politics in the United States: "So he won't run the hundred in ten seconds flat / So he won't have a pretty jump shot, or be an Olympic acrobat / So he won't know much about global warming / Is that really where you're at? / He won't be the brightest, perhaps / But he'll be the whitest / And I'll vote for that" (Genius Lyrics). Newman confirmed in an interview with Rolling Stone in 2012 that the song is a reaction the the Republican party, which has a history of climate change denial and climate change skepticism (Rolling Stone).

works.notes: Bad Religion's "Modern Day Catastrophists" is included in the database for a strong implicit reference to climate change. Although the song is focused on skepticism of religious figures promoting Catastrophism and other viewpoints, the second verse focuses on environmental issues: "Temperature is rising above the odorous rain / Well maybe it's a light of what we throw away / If we don't reuse what's around and free / Our kids can't throw away their comic book fee" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Given the group's habit of specifically referencing climate change in later songs (Kyoto Now!, Changing Tide), and the incredibly specific attention paid to other environmental issues like the hole in the ozone layer in their 1990 song Unacceptable, the lyric "Temperature is rising" almost certainly references global warming, a topic already part of mainstream political discourse by 1993 (Genius lyrics).

works.notes: Thom Yorke's "Cymbal Rush" is included in the database based on vague references to both sea level rise and ocean warming, combined with other context tying the song to climate change, including the songwriter's involvement in climate activism and the album art's relationship to climate change. The opening lyrics describe inescapable rising water levels, at one point implying temperature rise with the phrase "boiling over:" "Try to build a wall that is high enough / It's all boiling over, all boiling over / Mmm, mmm / Try to save your house, try to save your songs / Try to run but it follows you up the hill / It's all boiling over, all boiling over" (Genius Lyrics, audio track). Thom Yorke is a known environmental activist, taking action with groups including 350.org and Friends of the Earth, organizing environmentally conscious concert tours, and appearing at climate-change focused events. In a 2006 interview with The Chicago Tribune, Yorke described a connection between the album's artwork (a depiction of King Canute attempting to hold back a flood engulfing London) and the writing of environmentalist Jonathan Porritt comparing King Canute's failure to the United Kingdom's response to climate change.

works.work_title: In This Together with Ellie Goulding
works.notes: "In This Together," a collaboration between film composer Steven Price and singer Ellie Goulding for the "Our Planet" Netflix documentary series, is included in the database for an implicit reference to climate change in the lyrics combined with the explicit climate change content featured in the documentary itself and the music video released for the song on Netflix's YouTube channel. In the lyrics, the line "The sun will rise, but this time, it's so bright" implicitly calls to mind the idea of global warming amid more general reflections on a collective failure to address environmental issues (Genius Lyrics). Beyond this implicit reference documentary itself directly covers the impact of global warming on conservation efforts (Wikipedia). The music video for the song posted by Netflix on YouTube includes footage of melting glaciers, further cementing the song's relevance to climate change (YouTube).

works.notes: "This Side" is included in the database for an explicit reference to climate change. In the third verse, Doctur Dot includes these lines amid layered descriptions of triumph and urban struggle: "Rick James, Charlie Murphy, I'm a product of the chitlin circuit / I'm a product of the need to purchase / Drop bars like I'm losing service / Roll my R's when I feel exotic / Hit the blunt like a damn pinãta, ayy caramba / I was a beast, now I'm the jungle / Now I'm the wind, now I'm the rain, the climate change / I crack a joke to hide the pain, it doesn't work / We scratch the surface, we tip the bird / Don't give a fuck, we not concerned, it could be worse" (Genius Lyrics, audio track).

works.notes: "The Iris of the World" by Bruce Cockburn is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming and possible nautical metaphor for inaction on climate change. In the second verse, Cockburn mentions global warming as part of two lines that express temperature contrast: "In the age of global warming / When all things are growing colder" (Genius Lyrics). Although the reference is unconfirmed, the first verse of the song mentions sailors trying to plug holes in a ship that is on fire, which could be a metaphor for ineffective interventions to prevent climate change: "They're trying to plug holes in the hull / While flames eat up the deck / The captain and his crew / Don't seem to get the disconnect" (Genius Lyrics).

works.work_title: Turn Up the Heat and Chill the Rosé
works.notes: Jimmy Buffet's "Turn Up the Heat and Chill the Rosé" is included in the database for an explicit reference to global warming within a long and whimsical description of drinking chilled wine in various locations, including the North and South Pole. The song focuses on the contrast between temperatures throughout, following Buffet's typical pattern of singing about drinking and having a good time on the beach: "So turn up the heat and chill the rosé / Take off your Ugg's and let your metatarsals play / Even though the South of France is 10,000 miles away / We can turn up the heat and chill the rosé" (Genius Lyrics). The global warming reference appears at the end of the song and appears to be included to reinforce the temperature contrast motif: "So turn up the heat and chill the rosé / Stretch out on the beach and let your metatarsals play / Even though the ocean's frozen and there's mountains of sorbet / We'll survive this global warming if you chill the rosé" (Genius Lyrics).

releases.notes: Testament's third studio album.
AHNOHNI's debut solo album, nominated for a Mercury Prize in 2016.
Childish Gambino released the EP "Summer Pack" during the summer of 2018. The music video for the hit "Feels Like Summer" features cartoon depictions of numerous black celebrities.

Rust in Peace is Megadeth's fourth studio album and one of their most popular. It is the first album to showcase the classic lineup of founding members Dave Mustaine and David Ellefson with lead guitarist Marty Friedman and drummer Nick Menza. The album is considered one of the best examples of the thrash metal genre, and features lyrical themes such as alien conspiracies, mythology, and nuclear annihilation.
The Gathering is Testament's eighth studio album. The album includes elements of death metal, departing from the group's previous focus on thrash metal.
From Mars to Sirius is Gojira's third studio album, released on Listenable/Prosthetic records.
Astro Lounge is Smash Mouth's second studio album, released on Interscope Records.
"Solutions" is K.Flay's third studio album, release on Interscope and Night Street.
"Subliminal Criminals" is Stray From The Path's seventh studio album. The album contains environmental themes, including cover art showing a dead bird surrounded by plastic trash.
"Black on Both Sides" is the debut studio album by Mos Def. It features live instruments and socially conscious lyrics.
The Process of Belief is Bad Religion's twelfth studio album, released on Epitaph Records.
"Acoustic" is a compilation album released by Above & Beyond of acoustic arrangements of previously released music.
Sirens of the Sea is OceanLab's debut album, released on Anjunabeats records.

releases.release_title: I Need to Wake Up (An Inconvenient Truth)
releases.notes: The 2006 documentary "An Inconvenient Truth," narrating Al Gore's campaign to educate the public about climate change, was scored by Michael Brook with an accompanying theme song played during the end credits by Melissa Etheridge (Wikipedia). Etheridge's single "I Need to Wake Up" was released on Island records.

"The Eraser" is Thom Yorke's debut solo album, released on the independent label XL Records. The album art consists of a drawing of a man in a top hat holding back the waters of a great flood, which was inspired by the legend of King Canute failing to command the ocean. The artwork was partially chosen in response to environmentalist Jonathan Porritt comparing the British Government's actions to tackle climate change to the failure of King Canute (Wikipedia).

"Global Warming" is Pitbull's seventh studio album, released on Mr. 305, Polo Ground, and Reprise Records. The album is notably named after global warming, and is not his only album title reference to climate change. Pitbull named a 2017 album "Climate Change" and his 2013 EP "The Meltdown."

Pitbull's "Meltdown EP", released after the full-length album "Global Warming," was released on Mr. 305, Polo Grounds, and RCA Records. The title makes an implicit reference to ice melt caused by climate change when taken in context with the cover art (displaying a silhouette of Pitbull in front of a globe), the names of Pitbull's other climate-themed albums ("Global Warming" and "Climate Change"), and a later release of "Global Warming" and "The Meltdown" together titled "Global Warming: Meltdown" (Wikipedia).

"Climate Change" is Pitbull's tenth studio album, released on RCA Records, Polo Grounds Music, and Mr. 305 Inc (Wikipedia). The album's name is one of several references to the climate in Pitbull's discography (other album titles include "Global Warming" and "Meltdown EP").

Macy Gray released a single of her own song "All I Want For Christmas" (not to be confused with "All I Want for Christmas is You," another popular Christmas Song). It was licensed to YouTube by BMI and various other groups.
releases.link_1_title: Youtube - All I Want For Christmas

releases.release_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power
releases.notes: Music for the 2017 climate change documentary "An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power" was composed by Jeff Beal. OneRepublic contributed the single "Truth to Power" to the soundtrack.
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power

releases.release_title: When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?
releases.notes: "When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?" is Billie Eilish's debut album. It was written in collaboration with her brother, Finneas O'Connell, and produced at his apartment in Los Angeles (Wikipedia).
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?

releases.notes: "The 2nd Law" is Muse's sixth studio album, released on Warner Brothers records and the band's own Helium-3 imprint. The album title is a reference to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, which states that entropy of isolated systems left to spontaneous evolution cannot decrease (Wikipedia).

"Plastic Beach" is Gorillaz' third studio album, released on Parlophone and Virgin Records (Wikipedia). The album's title and artwork make explicit references to the environmental issue of plastic pollution, a theme that appears in the lyrics alongside climate change.

"How Dare You," recorded by John Meredith using a sample of climate activist Greta Thunberg's U.N. speech, was released as a single on Despotz Records via Bandcamp. Record company proceeds are directed to environmental advocacy group Greenpeace.
"The Anthropocene Extinction" is Cattle Decapitation's sixth studio album, released on Metal Blade Records.

Fatboy Slim performed a live show at Liverpool in which his song "Right Here, Right Now" was remixed with parts of Greta Thunberg's 2019 speach at the United Nations. Cell phone recordings of the song have been uploaded to YouTube.
releases.link_1_title: YouTube - Right Here, Right Now Fatboy Slim Greta Thunberg Edition Liverpool

releases.notes: We are 3Unit and... is 3Unit's only full length album, released independently.

releases.release_title: The Wolf is At The Door
releases.notes: "The Wolf is at the Door," a song written and performed by Reply All host Alex Goldman, was independently released as a single on Bandcamp. Goldman played guitars and synthesizers and sang for the recording.
"Notes On A Conditional Form" is the fourth studio album by The 1975.
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - Notes On A Conditional Form

releases.notes: Lil Dicky's song "Earth" (and its music video) were released three days before Earth Day in 2019 as a charity single. It was released on the Dirty Burd, Commission, and BMG record labels.

"Love Song To The Earth" is a charity single recorded by many famous artists to raise money for the environmental group Friends of the Earth. The complete list of artists: Paul McCartney, John Bon Jovi, Sheryl Crow, Fergie, Colbie Caillat, Natasha Beddingfield, Leona Lewis, Sean Paul, Johnny Rzeznik, Krewella, Angelique Kidjo, Kelsea Ballerini, Nicole Scherzinger, Christina Grimmie, Victoria Justice, and Q'Orianka Kilcher.
"Breakout" is Miley Cyrus' second studio album, released on Hollywood Records. It is her first album not released under the name Hannah Montana.
"Mirrorland" is the first major label studio album by EARTHGANG, released on Dreamville, Interscope, and Spillage Village.
"Optimist" is the debut studio album by Finneas, released on his record label OYOY and distributed by Interscope.
"A Beautiful Lie" is 30 Seconds to Mars' second studio album, released on Virgin Records (Wikipedia).

releases.release_title: Before the Flood (Music from the Motion Picture)
releases.notes: Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross composed much of the film score for Fisher Stevens' 2016 Climate Change documentary "Before the Flood." The album also contains significant contributions from Mogwai and Gustavo Santaolalla. All of the tracks on the album are instrumental except for "A Minute to Breathe," but many have names referencing climate change in the context of the film, including "Thin Ice" and "After the Flood" (Wikipedia).

"Drogas Wave" is the seventh studio album by Lupe Fiasco, released on 1st and 15th productions and Thirty Tigers. The concept of the album, which was planned as part of a trilogy, tells the story of slaves thrown overboard a trans-Atlantic slave ship who did not die but became powerful underwater forces, attacking other slave ships (Wikipedia).
"Radio Music Society" is the fourth studio album by Esperanza Spalding, released on Heads Up International.
Colorado is Neil Young's 39th studio album, released on Reprise, and it is one of many with the band Crazy Horse (Wikipedia).
"Kid A" is Radiohead's fourth studo album, released on Parlophone. It departed from the band's previous alternative rock style and remains one of their most critically acclaimed albums (Wikipedia).
"Distance over Time" is Dream Theater's fourteenth studio album, released on Inside Out.
"Quadra" is Sepultura's fifteenth studio album, released on Nuclear Blast and BMG Brazil.
"Humanity: Hour I" is Scorpions' sixteenth studio album, released on RCA/Sony BMG and New Door/UME. It is a concept album about a futuristic war between humans and androids (Wikipedia).

"Flying Microtonal Banana," subtitled 'Explorations into Microtonal Tuning, Volume 1,' is the ninth studio album by King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, released on Flightless Records, ATO, and Heavenly Recordings.
"Gumboot Soup" is the thirteenth studio album by King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard, released on Flightless.

"Infest the Rats' Nest" is King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard's fifteenth studio album, released on Flightless and ATO. This album departs from the group's psychedelic rock sound and stylistically explores heavy metal, specifically thrash metal.
"True North" is Bad Religion's sixteenth studio album, released on Epitaph.
"Recipe For Hate" is Bad Religion's seventh studio album, released on Epitaph and later re-released on Atlantic.
"The Last Hero" is Alter Bridge's fifth studio album, released on Napalm and Caroline.
"The War on Errorism" is the ninth studio album by NOFX, released on Fat Wreck chords.
"Strong" is Arrested Development's sixth studio album, released on Vagabond and Cutting Edge. It was released in Japan first, followed by the United States in January 2010.
"The Big Thrill" is Axxis' third full-length studio album, released on EMI.

"Welcome to The Future (Season 1)" is Brandon Lowry's second album using the name "Baby FuzZ," self-produced by himself and Nic Coolidge and released on Spotify under Take This to Heart records (Wikipedia, YouTube, Spotify). The single "Welcome to The Future" was released ahead of the album on December 4th, 2020 (YouTube).
"The Rebirth of Venus" is Ben Lee's seventh studio album, released on New West Records.
"Child of the Same God" is Bill Madden's fourth album, released independently.
releases.link_1_title: Bill Madden Discography - Child of the Same God

releases.notes: "Flying Colours" is the third album by Bliss n Eso, released on Illusive Sounds.
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - Flying Colours (Bliss n Eso album)

releases.notes: "Blue Hearts" is the fourteenth solo album by Bob Mould, released on Merge.
"Ride Out" is Bob Seger's seventeenth studio album, released on Capitol.
"Moonshine in the Trunk" is the eleventh studio album by Brad Paisley, released on Arista Nashville.

"Big Circumstance" is the sixteenth full-length album by Bruce Cockburn, released on True North Records. It was recorded in July-August of 1988. Copyrights on the album notes show the date as 1988, but an initial search of releases did not reveal any version released before January 1st, 1989.
"Wave One - EP" is the first release by Cody Simpson's band Cody Simpson & The Tide, released on Entertainment One Music.
"Counterfeit Blues" is the eighth studio album by Corb Lund, released on New West.
"Whoosh!" is Deep Purple's twenty-first studio album, released on earMUSIC.
"Lust For Life" is Lana Del Rey's fifth studio album, released on Polydor, Interscope, and Urban.
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - Lust for Life (Lana Del Rey Album)

releases.notes: "Asylum" is Disturbed's fifth studio album, released on Reprise Records.
"Cass County" is the fifth solo studio album by Don Henley, released on Past Masters Holdings and Capitol Records.
Give Up is the only studio album by American electronic duo The Postal Service, released on February 18, 2003, by Sub Pop Records (Wikipedia).

"carbon" is the second studio album recorded by Sirintip, released on October 14th, 2022 on Ropeadope Records. The album's thematic material is explicitly connected to climate change. According to the album notes published on Bandcamp, this album reflects "three years of climate research and patient self-discovery" and presents "thirteen tracks of original music as an invitational gesture, an appeal for a new kind of conversation around climate action" (Bandcamp).

"LIES THEY TELL OUR CHILDREN" is the 13th album by Anti-Flag, released on January 6th, 2023 on Spinefarm records (yahoo.com). Several of the tracks were released in late 2022 in videos and pre-releases.
releases.link_1_title: yahoo!entertainment - Anti-Flag Announce New Album, ‘Lies They Tell Our Children’

releases.notes: Appeal to Reason is the fifth studio album by American rock band Rise Against, released on October 7, 2008 on DGC/Interscope.
Wolves is the eighth studio album by the American rock band Rise Against. It was released on June 9, 2017 on Virgin Records (Wikipedia).

The Underworld is the second studio album by the American thrash metal band Evildead, released on Steamhammer Records (Wikipedia). The album was released in June of 1991 but the exact date of the release is unknown.
United States of Anarchy (stylized as United $tate$ of Anarchy) is the third studio album by the American thrash metal band Evildead, released on October 30, 2020 (Wikipedia).

This is the soundtrack album for the 2019 Netflix Documentary Series "Our Planet," narrated by David Attenborough (Wikipedia). The soundtrack was released with a compilation of the incidental music specially commissioned for Our Planet (Wikipedia). The theme song "In This Together", which is a collaboration with English singer and songwriter Ellie Goulding, is included.

A Flash Flood of Colour is the third studio album by English rock band Enter Shikari, and was produced by Dan Weller. It was released internationally on 16 January 2012 by Ambush Reality, the band's record label in the United Kingdom, and Hopeless Records in North America (Wikipedia).

releases.release_title: One Day Son, This All Will Be Yours
releases.notes: One Day Son, This Will All Be Yours is the second studio album by British post-hardcore band Fightstar, released on 24 September 2007 through Institute Recordings, itself a subsidiary of independent label Gut Records (Wikipedia).
releases.link_1_title: Wikipedia - One Day Son, This All Will Be Yours

releases.release_title: When The North Pole Melts (live performance)
releases.notes: "When The North Pole Melts" was performed live at the Climate Institute's Second North American Conference on Preparing for Climate Change in 1988 by Captain Sea Level and The Environmental Protection Agency Chorus (song.risingsea.net). A recording of the live performance was not found, but a self-released studio recording of the song from 1988 is documented in the database.
Finneas released "Where The Poison Is" as a single on November 7th, 2020, hours after Donald Trump was defeated by Joe Biden in the the 2020 U.S. Presidential Election (Rolling Stone).
releases.link_1_title: Rolling Stone - Finneas Marks Trump’s ‘Firing’ With New Song ‘Where the Poison Is’
