artists.notes: James William Buffett was an American musician and singer-songwriter. He was best known for his tropical rock music, which often portrayed a lifestyle described as "island escapism" and promoted enjoying life and following passions (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Pattie Gonia
artists.notes: Wyn Wiley, known professionally as Pattie Gonia, is a drag queen, environmental and LGBTQ+ activist, and community organizer. Pattie Gonia's activism focuses on environmental and LGBTQ+ issues, promoting acceptance of queer identities in the environmentalist and outdoors communities, and promoting awareness of climate change and its effects (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Gucci Mane
artists.notes: Radric Delantic Davis., known professionally as Gucci Mane, is an American rapper and record executive. He is credited as a pioneer of the hip hop subgenre trap music, along with fellow Atlanta-based rappers T.I. and Jeezy, as the style gained mainstream popularity into the 2000s and 2010s (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Sacrifice
artists.notes: Sacrifice is a Canadian thrash metal band from Toronto, Ontario. The band was formed by guitarists Rob Urbinati and Joe Rico in 1983. Sacrifice played a prominent role in the 1980s underground metal scene in Toronto, and along with Voivod, Razor and Annihilator, they are considered one of the "Big Four" of Canadian thrash metal (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Sherwin Linton
artists.notes: Sherwin Linton is a country musician from South Dakota. Linton is known for a series of country music singles, albums, TV appearances, and tours in the 1960s, 70s, and 80s, including a well-regarded tribute album to Johnny Cash (sherwinlinton.com).
artists.link_2_title: ABC Newspapers -  Sherwin Linton celebrates 60 years of show business

artists.name: Melissa Schiller
artists.notes: Melissa Schiller (also listed as Melissa Schiller & the Baker-Miller Pinks) is an independent pop rock artist from Davis, California.
artists.link_1_title: Bandcamp - Melissa Schiller & the Baker-Miller Pinks

artists.name: Chali 2Na
artists.notes: Charles Stewart, better known as Chali 2na, is an American painter and rapper, associated with the groups Jurassic 5 and Ozomatli. He is known for his bass-baritone and quick delivery rapping style (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Chamillionaire
artists.notes: Hakeem Temidayo Seriki, better known by his stage name Chamillionaire, is an American rapper from Houston, Texas (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Dweezil Zappa
artists.notes: Dweezil Zappa is an American rock guitarist and occasional actor. He is the son of musical composer and performer Frank Zappa. Exposed to the music industry from an early age, Zappa developed a strong affinity for playing the guitar and producing music. Dweezil Zappa has released numerous solo albums and performed as a guest on many recordings, in addition to touring with the group Zappa Plays Zappa (Wikipedia),

artists.name: Crack the Sky
artists.notes: Crack the Sky is an American progressive rock band formed in Weirton, West Virginia, in the early 1970s. They enjoyed praise from music critics in the 1970s and opened for many major acts such as Frank Zappa (Rolling Stone). They are still active and maintain a particularly dedicated local fanbase in Baltimore, Maryland (Wikipedia, Rolling Stone).
artists.link_2_title: Rolling Stone - Crack the Sky: The Strange Survival Story of the Best U.S. Prog Band You’ve Never Heard

artists.name: Matt Farley
artists.notes: Matt Farley is an American filmmaker, musician, and songwriter who has released more than 24,000 songs as of July 2023, and according to his fandom page, 25,000 songs as of January 2024 (Wikipedia, fandom.com). His music is released under a variety of band names and his often satirical or novelty-themed songs cover a stunning breadth of topics, including food, sports teams, cosmic phenomena, bodily fluids, and politics.

artists.name: Dance Gavin Dance
artists.notes: Dance Gavin Dance is an American rock band from Sacramento, California, formed in 2005. The band is known for experimental musical styles including math rock and progressive rock (Wikipedia).

artists.name: Solo Borges
artists.notes: Solo Borges is an American heavy metal band from New Jersey (Encyclopaedia Metallum). The band is led by vocalist and guitarist Jorge Borges, who traveled to the United States from his home country of Argentina after finishing high school (soloborges.com). Borges is backed up by bassist Mario Menjivar and drummer Erik Drumz.

artists.name: Dreamcatcher
artists.notes: Dreamcatcher (Korean: 드림캐쳐) is a South Korean girl group formerly known as MINX. The group consists of seven members: JiU, SuA, Siyeon, Handong, Yoohyeon, Dami, and Gahyeon (Wikipedia). Dreamcatcher has released 3 full-length albums and numerous EPs, singles, and music videos.

artists.name: Fall Out Boy
artists.notes: Fall Out Boy is an American rock band formed in Wilmette, Illinois, a suburb of Chicago, in 2001. The band consists of lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist Patrick Stump, bassist Pete Wentz, lead guitarist Joe Trohman, and drummer Andy Hurley (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Rock
genres.notes: Broad genre of popular music originating in the United States in the 1940s and 1950s with heavy influence from Rhythm & Blues and Country music. Very focused on the electric guitar and became extremely influential in the US and UK in the 1960s and onwards.

genres.name: Pop
genres.notes: Contemporary, popular music. Often distinguished by a danceable rhythm or beat, simple melodies and a repeating structure. Pop song lyrics are often emotional, relating to love or dancing (New World Encyclopedia).

genres.name: R&B
genres.notes: A style of popular music that originated as Rhythm and Blues in the 1940s in the United States, reflecting the interests of urban black communities. Contemporary R&B now may include elements of funk, jazz, hip-hop, and electronic music.

genres.name: Heavy Metal
genres.notes: A subgenre of rock music characterized by aggressive rhythms, overdriven guitars, and dark lyrical themes.

genres.name: Hip Hop
genres.notes: Hip Hop is a genre of popular music developed in the United States by inner-city African Americans and Caribbean Americans in the Bronx borough of New York City in the 1970s.

genres.name: Punk
genres.notes: Punk, or punk rock, emerged in the 1970s as a subgenre of rock music. Punk is characterized by "short, fast-paced songs with hard-edged melodies and singing styles, stripped-down instrumentation, and often shouted political, anti-establishment lyrics" (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Electronic
genres.notes: Electronic is a genre of music that employs electronic musical instruments, digital instruments, or circuitry-based music technology in its creation (Wikipedia). Electronic music includes many subgenres, including Electronic Dance Music (EDM), House, Trance, and Techno.

genres.name: Christmas
genres.notes: Christmas music spans many genres but is related to celebrations of Christmas, the Christian holiday celebrating the birth of Jesus.

genres.name: Jazz
genres.notes: Jazz is a music genre that originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans, Louisiana in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with its roots in blues and ragtime (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Alternative Rock
genres.notes: Alternative rock (also known as alternative music, alt-rock, or simply alternative) is a category of rock music that emerged from the independent music underground of the 1970s and became widely popular in the 1990s. "Alternative" refers to the genre's distinction from mainstream or commercial rock or pop music (Wikipedia).
genres.link_2_title: Wikipedia - List of alternative rock artists

genres.name: Indie
genres.notes: Independent music (also commonly known as indie music or simply indie) is music that is produced independently from commercial record labels or their subsidiaries, a process that may include an autonomous, do-it-yourself approach to recording and publishing. The term indie is sometimes used to describe a genre (such as indie rock and indie pop), and as a genre term, "indie" may or may not include music that is independently produced, and many independent music artists do not fall into a single, defined musical style or genre and create self-published music that can be categorized into diverse genres (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Country
genres.notes: Country (also called country and western) is a genre of popular music that originated with blues, church music such as Southern gospel and spirituals, old-time, and American folk music forms including Appalachian, Cajun, Creole, and the cowboy Western music styles of New Mexico, Red Dirt, Tejano, and Texas country. Its popularized roots originate in the Southern and Southwestern United States of the early 1920s (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Soundtrack
genres.notes: This genre is included to capture music that was recorded for films about climate change.

genres.name: World
genres.notes: World music is an English phrase for styles of music from non-Western countries, including quasi-traditional, intercultural, and traditional music (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Folk
genres.notes: Folk music is a music genre that includes traditional folk music and the contemporary genre that evolved from the former during the 20th-century folk revival. Some types of folk music may be called world music. Traditional folk music has been defined in several ways: as music transmitted orally, music with unknown composers, music that is played on traditional instruments, music about cultural or national identity, music that changes between generations (folk process), music associated with a people's folklore, or music performed by custom over a long period of time. It has been contrasted with commercial and classical styles. The term originated in the 19th century, but folk music extends beyond that. Starting in the mid-20th century, a new form of popular folk music evolved from traditional folk music. This process and period is called the (second) folk revival and reached a zenith in the 1960s. This form of music is sometimes called contemporary folk music or folk revival music to distinguish it from earlier folk forms. Smaller, similar revivals have occurred elsewhere in the world at other times, but the term folk music has typically not been applied to the new music created during those revivals. This type of folk music also includes fusion genres such as folk rock, folk metal, and others. While contemporary folk music is a genre generally distinct from traditional folk music, in U.S. English it shares the same name, and it often shares the same performers and venues as traditional folk music.

genres.name: Musicals
genres.notes: Musical theatre is a form of theatrical performance that combines songs, spoken dialogue, acting and dance. The story and emotional content of a musical – humor, pathos, love, anger – are communicated through words, music, movement and technical aspects of the entertainment as an integrated whole. Although musical theatre overlaps with other theatrical forms like opera and dance, it may be distinguished by the equal importance given to the music as compared with the dialogue, movement and other elements. Since the early 20th century, musical theatre stage works have generally been called, simply, musicals (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Reggae
genres.notes: Reggae is a music genre that originated in Jamaica in the late 1960s. The term also denotes the modern popular music of Jamaica and its diaspora. Reggae usually relates news, social gossip, and political commentary. It is instantly recognizable from the counterpoint between the bass and drum downbeat and the offbeat rhythm section. Reggae is deeply linked to Rastafari, an Afrocentric religion which developed in Jamaica in the 1930s, aiming at promoting pan-Africanism (Wikipedia).

genres.name: Singer-Songwriter
genres.notes: A singer-songwriter is a musician who writes, composes, and performs their own musical material, including lyrics and melodies. Singer-songwriters often provide the sole accompaniment to an entire composition or song, typically using a guitar or piano (Wikipedia).

genres.name: K-pop
genres.notes: K-pop, short for Korean popular music, is a form of popular music originating in South Korea as part of South Korean culture. It includes styles and genres from around the world, such as pop, hip hop, R&B, rock, jazz, gospel, reggae, electronic dance, folk, country, disco, and classical on top of its traditional Korean music roots.[3] The term "K-pop" became popular in the 2000s, especially in the international context. Modern K-pop "idol" culture began in the 1990s, as K-pop idol music grew into a subculture that amassed enormous fandoms of teenagers and young adults (Wikipedia).

themes.name: Wildfires
themes.notes: While wildfires are not climatic events themselves, wildfire conditions in many regions are being exacerbated by climate change, notably via droughts and heat waves creating dry vegetation.
themes.link_1_title: Briefing: Climate and wildfire in western U.S. forests

themes.name: Melting Ice
themes.notes: Global warming is causing sea ice and land ice to melt in many regions.
themes.link_1_title: EPA - Climate Change Indicators: Snow and Ice

themes.name: Climate Activism
themes.notes: Climate activism is the process of advocating for public awareness of climate change and policy changes to address it. Many individuals and organizations engage in climate activism. Famous climate activists include Varshini Prakash, one of the leaders of Sunrise Movement, and Greta Thunberg, an organizer of Fridays for Future and student climate strikes.

themes.name: Carbon Emissions
themes.notes: Carbon emissions refer to carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere. While carbon naturally flows in and out of the atmosphere in the carbon cycle, human activities such as burning fossil fuels have released enough to cause accumulation in the atmosphere. Because carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas, it results in global warming and climate change via the greenhouse effect (NASA).

themes.name: Sea Level Rise
themes.notes: Global sea levels are rising as a result of human-caused global warming. Sea level rise is caused primarily by two factors related to global warming: the added water from melting ice sheets and glaciers and the expansion of seawater as it warms (NASA).

themes.name: Floods
themes.notes: Climate change is increasing the probability of heavy precipitation events associated with flood damages (PNAS).
themes.link_1_title: PNAS - Contribution of historical precipitation change to US flood damages

themes.name: Droughts
themes.notes: As average temperatures have risen because of climate change, the Earth’s water cycle has sped up through an increase in the rate of evaporation from soil and transpiration from plants. An increase in evapotranspiration makes more water available in the air for precipitation, but contributes to drying over some land areas, leaving less moisture in the soil. As the climate continues to change, many historically wet areas are likely to experience increased precipitation... and increased risk of flooding..., while historically dry areas are likely to experience less precipitation and increased risk of drought. As a result, since the 1950s, some regions of the world have experienced longer and more intense droughts, particularly in southern Europe and West Africa, while other regions have seen droughts become less frequent, less intense, or shorter (for example, in central North America) (EPA).

themes.name: Deforestation
themes.notes: Cutting down or burning forests releases the carbon stored in their trees and soil, and prevents them from absorbing more CO2 in the future. Since 1850, about 30% of all CO2 emissions have come from deforestation (MIT).
themes.link_1_title: MIT Climate Portal - Forests and Climate Change

themes.name: Climate Change
themes.notes:
It is unequivocal that human influence has warmed the atmosphere, ocean and land. Widespread and rapid
changes in the atmosphere, ocean, cryosphere and biosphere have occurred (IPCC). This theme is used for songs that use the term "climate change" explicitly.
themes.link_1_title: PCC, 2021: Summary for Policymakers. In: Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Sixth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

themes.name: Climate Denial
themes.notes: Climate denial is the effort to discredit the scientific consensus over man-made global warming.
themes.link_1_title: European Association for American Studies - - The Ideology of Climate Change Denial in the United States
themes.link_2_title: PNAS - In climate news, statements from large businesses and opponents of climate action receive heightened visibility

themes.name: Warming
themes.notes: Warming refers to the observed increase in global surface temperatures caused by human activities relative to levels during the period from 1850-1900 (see IPCC AR6 SPM A.1.2 and Figure SPM.1, SPM.2). This theme is used for songs that describe warming or simply reference "Global Warming" or the Greenhouse Effect.
themes.link_1_title: Climate Change 2021 - The Physical Science Basis - Working Group I Contribution to the Sixth Assessment Report of the IPCC: Summary for Policymakers

themes.name: Renewable Energy
themes.notes: Renewable energy is energy produced from sources like the sun and wind that are naturally replenished and do not run out. Renewable energy can be used for electricity generation, space and water heating and cooling, and transportation (energy.gov). Renewable energy is included as a theme in the database because renewable energy emits far fewer greenhouse gases than coal, gas, and oil and thus is vital to addressing climate change.

themes.name: Biodiversity Loss
themes.notes: According to Encyclopedia Brittanica, biodiversity loss is a decrease in biodiversity within a species, an ecosystem, a given geographic area, or Earth as a whole. Biodiversity, or biological diversity, is a term that refers to the number of genes, species, individual organisms within a given species, and biological communities within a defined geographic area, ranging from the smallest ecosystem to the global biosphere. (A biological community is an interacting group of various species in a common location.) Likewise, biodiversity loss describes the decline in the number, genetic variability, and variety of species, and the biological communities in a given area. This loss in the variety of life can lead to a breakdown in the functioning of the ecosystem where decline has happened. Climate change has been identified as a major cause of biodiversity loss (Encyclopedia Brittanica).

themes.name: Climate Migration
themes.notes: Climate migration refers to the displacement of people due to weather events, agricultural failures, and disasters exacerbated by climate change. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, "Hazards resulting from the increasing intensity and frequency of extreme weather events, such as abnormally heavy rainfall, prolonged droughts, desertification, environmental degradation, or sea-level rise and cyclones are already causing an average of more than 20 million people to leave their homes and move to other areas in their countries each year" (UNHCR).

themes.name: Ocean Acidification
themes.notes: In the 200-plus years since the industrial revolution began, the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere has increased due to human actions. During this time, the pH of surface ocean waters has fallen by 0.1 pH units. This might not sound like much, but the pH scale is logarithmic, so this change represents approximately a 30 percent increase in acidity. Ocean acidification is already impacting many ocean species, especially organisms like oysters and corals that make hard shells and skeletons by combining calcium and carbonate from seawater (NOAA).
